column4: I am leaving home with Simon Cantier as pianears to go with the Company of pianears to finde a location for the Saints Some whair in the west
Just arrived at the main camp on the west side of the Missouri river. Likely leave in the morning.
Leaving Winter Quarters with 6 of my teams
We've gone about 4 miles. We formed an encampment with several others in my division.
I am heading back to Winter Quarters for the conference tomorrow.
It has been decided that several of the Twelve, with a company of pioneers, numbering in all, 143 souls, will leave "Winter Quarters".
We intend to explore the country, and find a place the most suitable for forming a settlement.
Saints are gathering for the conference. Most of the Twelve are here. We expect to hear from President Young.
The conference included the sustaining of Church leaders and President Young speaking. It didn't go too long due to the cold weather.
Just arrived at the big Elk horn. We have fell in with 4 teams that started a little before us.
Spending the afternoon in counsel with my brethren and likely the rest of the day.
We have procured the following instruments preparatory to our exploring expedition...
...two sextants, one circle of reflection, two artificial horizons, two barometers, several thermometers, telescopes, &c.
Leaving my home in winter quarters. I'm riding in a wagon with Norton Jacob.
Pres. Young and others started and moved out 4 miles and camped. I have my wagon loaded and am prepared for starting.
Many saints want to follow. we have requested they wait for eight or ten weeks, until the weather should become warmer.
Those not in circumstances to follow us are requested to put in spring crops to sustain themselves, and emigrants from our eastern churches.
We crossed the Creek on a raft and camped to wate the arrival of the remainder of the Camp.
We just left winter Quarters with the Pioneers.
Spent all day making preparations for the journey. Should finish tomorrow.
We have only gone about half a mile today, and are now camping for the night.
We journeyed about 7 miles today.
I have called my family together and dedicated them unto the Lord. I pray we all meet again in the due time of the Lord.
Finishing the last of the preparations for the journey. We'll be ready to leave soon.
Parley P. Pratt returned from England. I started my wagon on the pioneer trip.
We're heading out from Winter Quarters today.
We just heard that P. P. Pratt had arrived from England
Calling my family together to give instructions on their duties, to bless them, dedicate, and consecrate them to the Most High God.
Brother Parley has returned to Winter Quarters from his mission in England. He looks well. The Twelve who have already left are coming back.
We traveled 6 miles today, and are now waiting for the rest of the camp to come up.
Meeting with Bro. Parley and the 12 in Dr. Richards' office. Such a delight to hear of the peace and prosperity of the Saints in England.
Leaving Winter Quarters with the Twelve. My son William is driving me, Pres. Young, and Bishop Whitney.
Camping tonight out on the open prairie.
Met up with the rest of the Camp, which was some distance outside Winter Quarters. Now we head west.
staid in camp this morning. Not sure when we will leave
Just hitched up, and we are heading out.
Bearing west after coming up the divide of Mt. Watters a few miles.
Just leaving camp now. We're headed toward Elk Horn
Traveled about 10 miles today. We've set up camp about 4 miles east of Pappea. Pres Young and I will sleep in the wagon.
I have started myself. One of my horses would not work and I sent him back. Traveled eleven miles.
Making camp in the open Prairie about 10 miles from our first encampment.
Traveled 8 miles and are now camped for the night
Whitney and I went out to pray for the Pioneers and the 12 for protection & angels to lead them to a resting place for the Lord's people.
Also prayed for our families, wives, children & for all of Israel left behind and for peace and prosperity to abide with them.
Just got to Elk Horn. Tomorrow we will ford the river.
Getting an early start across Poppy creek to find fuel so we can cook.
Started early and traveled all day. had a hard days work
Heading out with the camp and the teams toward Pappea, which I'm told means "butterfly."
At Pappea. We've reached a steep bank, so we're attaching ropes to the tongues of the wagons to help draw up the loads.
Struck the mouth of the Elkhorn River, continuing downriver to the old crossing.
Got all the wagons up the embankment safely and pressed on. We're within about 6 miles of Elk Horn and are making camp by a small grove of timber.
Several of the twelve (myself with others) crossed our teames using a raft as prepared by others that went ahead a few days earlier.
The day has passed peaceably. Some boys are dancing for fun. Dr. Richards' horse has wandered off, and we can't find it.
Camped seven miles east of the Horn Fork. I found my team too light and so got a yoke of cattle to help me on.
The Sabbath. Everyone rose in good spirits. Dr's horse is still missing. After breakfast, he's sending out several men to look for it.
Spent the day crossing the river on a raft. All have now crossed.
Dr's horse still lost, so I'm giving him my spare to lead his cattle. Pres Young loaned a team of oxen to George A Smith, as his failed.
Reached the Horn River and will spend the afternoon ferrying  wagons across. Some of the most beautiful country I've ever seen.
We're crossing the Horn on a raft.
Ferrying is done for the day: 72 wagons across. Still marveling at the beauty: cedars, rivers, rolling hills.
Traveled 5 miles so far today.  Just got to Elk Horn River and getting everyone across.  Imagine we'll camp on the other side.
In all there were 172 wagons and 136 pioneers that crossed the Horn. Dr. Willard Richards and my self were the last wagons that crossed.
We passed down the Horn about half a mile and formed a line, then we fed our horses on cottonwood, brush and corn.
Came up and crossed the Horn on a raft built by Tarleton Lewis; and Stephen A. H. Goddard. My wagon came near going off the raft.
The remainder of the Camp finished crossing. The creek is about ten rods wide at the fry and three feet and upwards deep.
This place is about 6 miles from the mouth-where it emptes into the Platt river.
Higbee killed a crane, racoon, and fish, and brought me one for dinner. Getting the camp safely together was important, even on the Sabbath.
All crossed and camped together on the west side the Horn where the Broad Bottom extended across to the Platte.
Brethren gathered, decided Camp should tackle up teams and proceed 12 miles quickly because we fear rain. Roads could be extremely bad.
The twelve are returning to Winter Quarters and I am accompanying them.
Company started up the Platt with instructions to stop at a part of timber about 12 miles up\ be doing some Blacksmithing and other work.
I am returning to Winter Quarters on horseback with the twelve.
The twelve have all left to go back to Winter quarters. We are going to resume our journey across to the Plat.
Camp underway with instructions to stop when they see the blacksmiths and to get any wagons or other items repaired as needed.
Bros [Brigham] Young, [Heber C.] Kimbel and some outhers retourned to hold a counsil with the remainder of the twelve that had just returned
We followed the bottom for about 15 miles. We are now camped on the bank of the Platt to wait for the return of the twelve.
Arrived at Winter Quarters. Elder Taylor has not yet arrived.
Traveled 12 miles today, we'll camp here.  Brigham Young, Heber Kimball and others crossed back over the Horn to return to Winter Quarters.
Returned with the 12 and others to Winter Quarters. Hoped to find Elder Taylor returned from England. He is not back. Families in good spirits.
All hands made arrangements to return on Wednesday and waited in faith for the accomplishment of the vote of the former councilor.
Got a wagon and driver ready. Now meeting with Brethren in Dr. Richards' office on church business. After, will rest at home for the night.
We decided that Bros. Grover, & Markham should take charge till the 12 come back. Markham told us to set guards, and observe prayers
The weather during this time had been cold and the spring is backward. There is some slight appearance of grass.
Brother Kimball just told me he wants me to go with the pioneers & drive an ox team for him. I need to consult with my family first.
I've decided to go. I'm leaving my wife and child in as good circumstances as I could wish, but they are poor at best.
Returned to Winter Quarters. Met in Council in the evening and continued to council until twelve o'clock.
I went to bed feeling very tired and much bruised by riding horseback thirty five miles on a rough going nag
Spending most of the day here at home. Thomas & James started for the farm.
Using every diligence to start out four ox teams as follows: one each for Pres. Young, myself, Dr. Richards, and David Grant.
Convinced Wm Clayton to go to the mtns with us, but is destitute. Agreed to give all his church records and documents to help outfit family.
I've got my clothes ready. I'm heading out with Bro. Everett, Jacobs, & Stephens.
John Taylor arrived from England. Prestnt Brig. Young called for us to meet in council in the evening.
Teusday- The Brethren commenced setting tire to their waggons, and we remaind in camp. Clara washed and I cleaned my wagon
Traveled 4 miles today. We've made camp in a hollow for the night.
went to the store & told Brigham & Heber about Hosea Stout’s calculations, &c
Elder T. arrived with the instruments and we are meeting in council, much to the Joy of our hearts
Elder Taylor has returned with $2,269, knives, tools, 144 articles in all--funds we need. Bro. Young is mouthpiece as we pray in gratitude.
I am making two axletrees for Heber C. Kimball's wagon.
I just received a quite lengthy lecture from Markham this evening about obeying council and about the first principle of the gospel.
Attended prayers and went to bed.
Just finished breakfast and were getting underway when we discovered 4 Omaha Indians on the ridge south of us.
Woke up this morning severely pained with rheumatism in my face
The Indians came begging and Bro. Everot told them that we was poor & not able to give our living away.
The Indians threatened to shoot a cow, but they have now left leaving us alone.
Council continued last night untill one a.m. Elders Taylor and Pratt presented instruments they procured in England for the pioneer company.
two artificial horizons, two sextants, one circle of reflection, two borometers, one telescopes and several thermometers.
Bidding my family farewell and leaving in a carriage with my son William and others. Another wagon goes too. We will reach the Camp soon.
Took leave of my family and started for my camp. My youngest child Nancy Adelia, born of Nancy Clement, has inflamation of the brain.
It is the opinion of most that she will not live but a few hours. Two others of my family are sick.
My oxen came up & several other teams came in from Winter Quarters.
Wensday- Looks like we'll remain in camp today.
Brigham & Dr [Willard] Richards came. B. told me to rise up and start with the pioneers in half an hours notice.
I delivered to him the records of the K of G. and set my folks to work to get my clothes together to start with the pioneers.
I left my family and started in Heber’s carriage with Heber and Wm. Kimball. Bishop Whitney and Amasa Lyman went with us in another wagon.
Stopping at the Pappea. Gathering wood because there will be no more until we reach the Elk Horn. Little good water today, just small holes.
Today was passes in the same way as the day preceding.
All returned to the Horn
Settling in after a hearty meal. Night pleasant but cool. Committed ourselves to God in prayer. Three men taking turns at guard tonight.
We went about 19 miles today, and are camping on the prarie. Heber just prayed, and I'm about to retire.
Started after eating and prayers by Bishop Whitney.
We're heading back over the Horn now after being gone for three days.
Camp was organized and we went that day a fue miles and camped. We numbered waggons 73 and 143 men.
Got the Elk Horn River.
Have reached the Elk Horn river. Bro Young, George A. Smith, Amasa Lyman, and Ezra Benson have just crossed ahead of us.
I finished up repairs of the wagon.
All across the Elk Horn and we have overtaken Brigham, G.A. Smith, E.T. Benson, and Amasa Lyman.
All the camp has gone on to the Platte excepting my team.
G.A. Smith's wagon is still here at the Horn.
We have arrived at the Pioneers Camp, about 12 miles from the Elk Horn and 47 miles from Winter Quarters.
Crossed Elk Horn by noon. Went 12 miles and just arrived at the Camp. We are 47 miles from Winter Quarters. All are eager to move forward.
We've caught some fish and found a bee tree. We're serving up a fine supper.
Brother O Pratt, Wilford Woodruff, George Smith, Amasa, Lyman and Erastus Snow joined us for supper
Brigham Young called us together and received instructions.
went 4 miles to whare we crossed the horn went to camp, distance 12 miles on the Platte River
Brothers Young, Kimball and others returned to camp. They took dinner with us
Overtook our teams and the company who were waiting according to instructions
Last evening Br Little arived from the eastern states in our midst. He gave us news of the eastern churches.
Br Little spoke of many friends Among wholm was our friend Col Kane who had remembered the Twelve & others by forwarding Presents to us.
We're having a nice breakfast.
This day is gloomy, windy and cold.
Brother Pratt is observing the sun with his sextant to gain the correct time.
President Young and Heber C. Kimball are coming from camp. We're helping them across the river.
Camp was called to prayer. Present, one hundred and forty three men, three women and two children. 72 wagons and a boat.
We have been called together by the order of Brother Brigham.
Camp called together and organized. 2 captains of 100s viz Stephen Markham and A.P. Rockwood were appointed, also 5 captains of 50s.
There are 143 men and boys on the list of the pioneer company, three women and Lorenzo Young's two children. 73 wagons.
Gloomy, windy, and cold. Camp has gathered behind Bro Young's wagon to hear council and prepare for the journey.
A total of 148 souls have started to go West... to find a home where the Saints can live in peace.
S. Markham appointed the Captain of the Guard, and ordered to select out of the Camp, 50 men for guard, such as he had confidence in.
Company called together and numbered 143 men 3 women & 2 children
Brother Brigham has organized us by hundreds, fifties, and tens.
Speaking to the Camp. Exhorting them to be humble and faithful, for great things depend on it to ourselves, families, and the whole Church.
Bro. Whitney gave some good advice about obeying council and said he felt to bless us by all the authority he possessed before he left us.
Col Kane forwarded to me A Patent Life Preserver & Stop compass. Brother Little, P. Rockwell & J Reading are returning to winter quarters.
Prest. Young promised the company that if they would abide his council and observe his directions they should go safe and be Preserved.
I wrote a letter to Diantha [my wife], and put it into the hands of Bishop Whitney.
We're organizing the Pioneer camp with with 145 men, 3 women, 2 children and 73 wagons. We elect Stephen Markam to take command, also Shadrick Roundy and John Pack Major.
President Young organized us by appointing captains of hundreds, fifties and tens. Eight members of the Twelve, (captains) are among us.
Camp has been organized into 2 captains of 100s, 5 captains of 50s, 14 captains of 10s, plus a guard of 50.
Organization complete. Bishop Whitney's son John will keep a journal, so I fashioned him one. Some men are returning to Winter Quarters.
Company organized by appointing captains of tens fifties and hundreds.
We are now leaving, we will travel a short distance before camping for the night.
We're following on with the camp which are camped at the Platte.
The Camp started out to proceed on the journey. I bid farewell to Bp. Whitney and his brother and son, who all returned from this place.
Camp is moving out a few miles for better feed, cottonwood, rushes, timber. We'll spend the night there before continuing on our journey.
Company took march, each ten moveing in their place. Stephen Markham chosen as captain of 50 night guard.
Halting near an Island of rushes where we are turning out our teams to be guarded through the night.
I am chosen as the captain of the 13th ten.
We all hitched up and came up to the main camp, which is about eleven miles on the banks of the Platte.
We travelled about 3 miles [today] and encamped in a line abt. 600 yards from the timber, where there is plenty of Cotton Wood and rushes.
Just finished placing the horses and cattle in a good grove of timber with plenty of rushes- and extra guard was left to guard them.
My father let me have a yoke of cattle; rather poor and not well matched to help me on. Reached camp in the evening, very tired.
We traveled 5 miles & are now camped on the Platte Rriver. We organized the camp & a guard of 52 men ware deetayled to be a constant guard.
I slept with Philo Johnson, but having only one quit, and the night severely cold, I suffered much, and took a very bad cold.
this morning Bro Brigham organized the camp, then gave good council. traveled 4 miles and camped for the night
I was myself on duty the latter part of the night and it was very cold. There was considerable ice this morning.
The weather is severely cold, with a strong wind from the North & North West.
Cold and windy. Camp heading out for the day.
had a severe cold night. froze water an inch thick of ice.
We started out at 9 o'clock and travelled... the distance [of] about 7 miles. We camped close by a cotton wood grove.
We're camping now after traveling a short distance.
After 7 miles, we're stopping to camp. Men will cut down trees for brouse. Must fetch water from the river 1/2 mile away. Lake is bad water.
I'm looking for a piece of lumber to make a houn (sic) ????
traveled 7 miles and camped at 1 oclock. Bro Brigham finished organizing his camp
We traveled 8 miles today & camped at a cotton wood grove. We just organized the Camp in to a military capacity.
The Camp were called together and organized in military order: Brigham Young, Lieut. General. Stephen Markham, Colonel. etc.
Started up the Platt after 9, went seven miles and camped. A conference was called. We were formed into companies of tens.
The wagons must keep together when travelling, and not separate as they have previously done, and every man to walk beside his own wagon.
We travled 8 miles & camped in the edge of a grove of cottonwoods to spend the Sabbath. The organization of the camp finished in this order:
B Young Lieutenant Gen, S Markham Colonel, J Pack 1st Major, S Rounday 2d Major. The Rigiment be divided into tens. I am Capt of 1st company
One of the trader's wagons came from the Pawnee village, loaded with furs & Peltry, and camp about 1/4 of a mile below us.
Strict rules & disipline necessary while travling through Hostile indian country. some traiders came down from the Pawnees & camped with us.
Discussed military organization and safety. All men to carry loaded guns nearby. Wagons must keep together. Men to leave only by permission.
Eames & Hanson played some on their violins. All peace and quietness.
Some amused with violins and dance. Eames plans to return to Winter Quarters because of blood in his lungs. Will sleep in Young's wagon.
We now have a Brigadier Major, Lieutenant General, a Colonel and 2 Majors and a Captain over each ten. (I was elected captain over ten)
The night has been verrye colde, the ice has froze 3/4 of an inch thick, the young gras which was verrey scattering was considerabley killed
This day we went about 7 miles and camped. It was a colde day.
I wrote a letter for Heber to his wife Vilate which was sent by brother Ellis Eames who has concluded to go back on account of poor health.
I wrote A letter Home to Mrs Woodruff By Br Eames who wished to return back. I perused several papers to day, but did not find much news.
Today is Sunday.  It is a cold disagreeable day so we will have no meeting.
Today is Sunday, so the camp remains where we are.
The wind this morning E & S.E. and very cold, with a slight shower of snow.
Giving letter for wife Vilate for Eames to deliver to her. He's leaving for Winters Quarters now.
7 more traders' wagons came in and stopped about 1/4 of a mile below us, soon after 6 mules loaded with robes and furs.
More traders coming through Camp. They have many pelts and furs from the Pawnee village two days away.
Staid in Camp--cold weather.
I commenced writing Heber's journal & wrote considerable. He wants me to [write] his journal all the journey.
The weather more moderate and pleasant, the wind has changed near South and the sun shines.
Some traders past us from the Pawnee nation going to the Bluffs
Temperature 53 degrees. Ellis Eames returned with trading wagon and news from headquarters. Our proposed schedule follows:
James Case felled a cottonwood. A branch landed on his ox and one eye was pushed out of socket but went back, so he shouldn't be blind.
Being Sunday, today passed quietly. 7 waggons belonging to Mr. Sarpee of the fur company passed us on their way from Pawnee to the Bluffs.
Father James Case was cutting a cotton wood trees; just as it fell, the wind struck it and one of the limbs struck an ox on the neck.
[The ox's] right eye was knocked down in the socket out of sight. The ox don't seem seriously hurt otherwise.
[The ox's] eye turned back to its place, and the ox seems to have sustained little injury.
The officers of the camp met with Prest. Young, and he told the order for travelling and camping hereafter.
President. B. Young proposed we organize as a military body. Every man is to have a loaded gun at the ready.
New rules told to Camp: 5 am bugle call, 7 am traveling, men with loaded guns, 7:30 bugle to rest, instructions on how to circle wagons, &c.
The Bugle will be blown at half past 8 oclok at night when all will go to prayers in their several waggons & retire to bed by 9 oclok.
The Bugle will Blow at 5 oclok in the morning to arise & pray & two hours will be allotted to dress pray cook eat feed Horses Harness &c.
We will start at the blow of the Bugle at 7 oclok. this is the order of the camp.
4 shifts of 12 called to stand guard at night. We started at 2, traveled 4 miles up the Platt and camped at 4. Weather cool and cloudy.
Just received further traveling instructions.  The bugle is to sound a 6 o'clock in the morning when every person is to rise attend prayers and prepare to start.
The bugle is to sound again in the evening at half past eight when every man is to repair his wagon and attend prayers and retire to bed.
Everyone to prayers at the sound of the bugle at half past eight. In bed and the fires put out by nine. At five a.m. bugle sounds.
Teams are to travel by tens and not separate. No man is to leave his tent unless sent.
Went to bed suffering severely with pain in my head & face.
remaind in camp
I have been detailed to guard the fore part of the night
My Partner (who by the way was the Bugler) sounded the call for prayers and prepertions for moving.
At the sound of the bugle I arose, my face still paining me very bad. After eating breakfast I started out on foot.
The bugle comes early
starting out early today
Call sounded for moveing. We moved by tens every man except teamsters walking by his wagon with his gun upon his shoulders.
we are now starting on our journey. We are heading in a NW direction.
The wagons began to move... all formed in double file and proceeding on.
Half an hour into the day's journey, practicing wagons double file for safety. Many lakes and ducks. Some brethren shooting them.
Fine weather. moved on--
While Bateing our teams Porter Rockwell and Elder Jesse Carter came up with us from Winter Quarters. James Brown came as well.
The messes got back from Winter Quarters.
We've gone 13 miles and stopped for Dinner. Brother O. P. Rockwell and others has overtook us.
Arrived at a bend in the river where a small stream runs round an Island. We will stay here to feed a while, having travelled abt. 15 miles.
Feeding and resting horses at a bend in the river after 15 miles. Country level, roads good. Bottoms 10-15 miles wide, level and handsome.
Elder Little arived with P Rockwell & 2 others with the mail. I recieved 2 Letters. One was from Mrs Woodruff which I read with interest.
O.P. Rockwell, Jackson Redding, & J.C. Little came in from Winter Quarters. They have found Dr. Richards' mare which was lost.
O.P. Rockwell, Little and Jackson arrived from WQ with clothing for Little and Dr. Richard's mare lost at Elk Horn. Much rejoicing for mare.
[Rockwell, Redding, & Little] brought me a line from Diantha and one from Ruth & Margaret... I feel unworthy to posses two such treasures.
I received by Porter [Rockwell] some few fish hooks and lines, and a ball o fish line and 3 pencils.
The wagons began to move again, in the same order as this morning.
the Flat here is from 12 to 15 miles wide interspersed with numerous small lakes, the river is full of Isliands with several channels.
Suggested [to O. Pratt] the idea of fixing a set of wooden cog wheels to the hub of a wagon to tell the number of miles we travel each day.
Arrived at a very pretty open view of the Platte river, and the encampment was formed in a semicircle on its banks.
Camping at the Platte after 5 miles. Some tried to fish but the water is muddy and they caught only turtles, catfish, a duck and suckers.
We traveled about 22 miles today and camped on the banks of the Platt forming with our waggons a half circle on the River.
Travelled since noon about 5 miles and in the whole day 20 miles, over the same kind of dry, sandy, level bottom.
Dry level roads. Traveled 7 miles, rested, traveled 8 more miles and camped along the Platte. Porter Rockwell and three others rode in.
Went to brother Luke Johnson and asked him to draw my tooth which has pained me so bad for a long time.
S. Markham came up [to Luke Johnson] and asked him to take his team and leather boat back 2 miles to draw [for fish] in one of the lakes.
We traveled about 23 miles today.
traveled 7 more miles & camped for the night making 20 miles this day
traveled 25 miles and now camping for night. Bro Jesse Carter Little and Orrin Porter Rockwell returned from winter Quarters laden with letters
Arose; my head & face very bad indeed. I ate but little breakfast although we had a couple of ducks and a snipe.
John S. Higbee, Luke Johnson, S. Markham, and some others went about 2 miles farther to a lake and took over 200 nice fishes.
Started out; the morning pleasant except a strong West wind.
Have reached Shell Creek, clear water, only 6-8 feet wide. Traveling single file wagons today. So far have gone 5 miles.
Arrived at Shell creek, which is about 6 or 8 feet wide, and a poor bridge over it, but all the wagons got well over.
Crossing Shell Creek
5 more miles. Resting the horses at a creek. Porter Rockwell and Bro Brown saw 3 deer and are giving chase. The meat would be welcome.
Just spotted some pawne Indians. They appear to be quite friendly.
Stopped by a small slough or lake to feed and eat &c. being 5 miles from Shell creek.
We've come 12 miles today. O. Porter Rockwell chased 3 deer on the plains, but did not catch them.
Started again, the horse teams taking the lead.
Setting out again. The deer escaped after a 5-mile chase. The dust from the wagons is getting troublesome. Will likely go another 10 miles.
fine day verrey warm and dustey--
Rise, pray and be ready to start at 7 with guns at the ready. Any other bugle calls signal an alarm & <the> Camp is to form in a circle.
Our fisherman drew a net this afternoon & broat into camp 213 fish Buffalo & Carp which was divided in the camp
Making camp after traveling about 20 miles.
We went about 15 miles before camping today.
The encampment formed near a cotton wood grove on the banks of the river.
Caught a fine mess of fish--enough for the whole camp.
we caught upwards of 200 fish from a small lake which will afford our camp a rich repast
I went to the river and washed my feet which were very dusty and sore. I also washed my socks as well as I could in cold water without soap.
Set up camp an hour ago. Some men went fishing 2 miles west and just returned with 200 fish--we all get at least one. A first rate supper.
I went and asked [Luke Johnson] to draw my tooth. He willingly agreed, and got his instruments.
[Luke Johnson] lanced my gum, then took his nippers and jerked [my tooth] out. The whole operation did not take more than a minute.
[Johnson] only got half the original tooth, the balance being left in my jaw. After this my head and face pained me much worse than before.
Received a letter. My youngest daughter, Nancy Adelia, died. Thomas Kane sent a present of a hunting whip. Great boon as teamster is sick.
Crossed Shell Creek. Roads very good and level. Fishers brought in a fine lot of fishes (213), and buffalo. Distance, 18 miles.
traveled 12 miles and now camping for the night
Col Markam & John Higby & Some others obtained a quantity of fish so that when we got camped each man had a fish
My face [is] easier, but swelled and my gums raw. Took breakfast on fish and coffee, but ate not bread, it being very dry and hard.
Just as I was getting in bed O. P. Rockwell called me out to taste some good brandy presented to him by Thos. L. Kane. I gave him a toast
Started on foot, the ox teams being gone ahead. Some appearance of rain, and a slight shower is falling.
I stood guard the last watch.  We were left undisturbed.
Light rain as we travel. Sighted a Pawnee running full speed. He came and is shaking hands with all the Camp, but may be laying plans.
A lone indian has just been spotted.
Several more indians approach us from narrow skirt of timber
6 or 8 more Indians are running on foot in the distance, watching. We fear they may be planning to steal horses, &c. All precautions taken.
An Indian rode up to the first wagon and appeared very friendly. Soon after 6 or 8 others came running on foot.
Arrived at a fork in the road, the one on the left leading to the new Pawnee village, the one on the right leaving the village to the South.
Colde wind from the N.E. and clowdey and Signs of rain--we got in a fewe miles of the Pawnee Indian winter quarters and some fue came and met us
A consultation was held by Prest. Young with father Case relative to the roads [and] concluded to take the right hand road.
Indians are gone. They came up to us and extended the hand of friendship as if to say how de do
At a fork. Young asking Case which to take, as he's lived here. Case advises the north fork to avoid the Pawnee nation.
In sight of a Pawnee village.  They flocked around to gaze at us.
In sight of the new Pawnee village, in an open spot on the South bank of the loop fork, between 2 bodies of timber.
we stopt to bait opposite there camps which was on the outher side of the Loup Fork--The Chief and about 30 outhers soon geathered in.
they ware friendly and wanted presents and when we did not give them as mutch Powder led & tobacco &c as they wanted, they were dissatisfied
There are 2 large Pawnee Indian villages here. About 75 came into camp including the grand Chief of the Nation with many war Chiefs.
We're stopped by a loup fork of the Platte opposite a vilage of the Pawnees. Many Pawnees wading the river to come to us
We presented the Pawnee some Powder lead Salt tobacco, which was reluctantly receivd, making sighns that the pile was not big enoughf
One of the Indians presented certificates from persons who had previously travelled through the village, certifying they were friendly.
Approaching the new trading post on the loup fork
Formed encampment on the bank of the lake and instantly placed a guard at the passes, as many of the Indians had followed us.
We pass the Pawness. We try to give them presents but they aren't satisfied. We leave them mad at the loupe fork
Watering horses. Pawnee chief Shefmolan asking for gifts. I gave salt, tobacco, &c, others lead, flour, &c. Wants more from a large camp.
It seems traders, missionaries and and others are using with the Indians against us. Pawnee Chief not pleased with the trinkets we offered
Heber gave [the Indians] a little tobacco & a little salt & Prest. Young gave to the chief some powder, lead, and salt.
The old chief does not seem to think the presents sufficient, and said he did not like us to go west through their country.
There are about 12,000 of the Pawnees in this neighborhood, and it is reported that there are 5,000 warriors. We did not see many of them.
The ox teams started out again and the horse teams will start soon after.
Passed a Pawnee village. Presents made to the Indians while we rested. Chief appeared dissatisfied with our presents or our not stopping.
Left in spite of Shefmolan's dissatisfaction. Rain coming hard. Thunder and lightning look likely.
Gave Pawnee Indians about 4 lbs of tobacco 15 lbs lead powder fish Hooks beads flour salt &c. but still they were not satisfied.
We had a smart shower
Since there is no grass we are hauling grain and hay to feed our animals.
We attempt to ford the Loupe, but we are caught in the sand and need to be helped out. We decide to build a raft
We Pack the Sand so that all the loaded wagons can safely cross.
We are camped for the night.
Encampment formed. Bretheren called together & some remarks made by Prest. Young, advising them to have a strong guard 'round camp tonight.
The president speaks. He says that a man with covenants & getting his brethren to covenant is like a man binding bundles for his followers
We traveveld about 8 miles in the afternoon and are preparing the camp for action with a guard of fifty including 10 picket guards
The Indian chief was dissatisfied because we did not make them more presents.
thinking ourselves not entirely safe, we have traveled 8 more miles, and now a strong guard is posted of 50 men.
passed through the Pawnee settlement, we traveled 22 miles this day
Guarding the camp with many others. We fear the Pawnee may try thieving at night since we didn't give enough. My watch ends at 1.
The Indian fires are all around us, but a few guns and other demonstrations have let them know that we were on hand.
My face very painful again caused by the cold. There has been no trouble from the Indians and all is peace and safe.
I arise in the morn at the sound of the horn. Got to get the teams up and started.
The morning came in quietness and we resume our Journey as usual.
This morning is clear and cold.
Were not disturbed by Indians, but some guards were teased. They fell asleep, so others took their guns to show what could have happened.
The Camp proceeding again. I will go ahead on foot. Saw one of the prettiest beds of nettle I have seen for some time.
Crossing Looking Glass creek.
Just crosed the Looking glass crick about one mile from whare we ware camped last night
Sat down on an Indian grave, on top of a mound from whence is a splendid view of the surrounding country for many miles.
Baiting at the crossings of Beaver creek.
We've arived at Beaver Creek. There are some Beaver on this creek about one mile above its mouth.
Arrived on the East bank of the Beaver river, having travelled about 10 miles. Here we stop to feed.
Traveled 10 miles so far, resting at Bever river. Bank is steep, so the mean are leveling it to make crossing easier for the teams.
Eating Dinner on a beaver crick. We'll have to ford it after we eat
Started again with ox teams first. A number of the bretheren stood on the West bank with a long rope and assisted the teams up the bank.
Ox teams fording Bever first. We have men with ropes tied to wagon tongues to help drag them up the steep banks. River's only 2 feet deep.
traveling onto the old missionary stand of the Pawnee Nation.
We crossed Looking Glass and Beaver Creek today.
Viewed houses where the Pawnee dwelt. It looked lonesome. I thought those that were driven from there had suffered something as well as us.
Traveled 18 miles and camped at the Missionary Station at PLum Creek. Feed is good. Hay put up by our brethren last summer and corn fodder.
Lightening and thunder struck about 3 PM. We camped at the Loup Fork about 9 PM. Distance, 22 miles. Wind raised until bed time.
Arriving at Pawnee Village mission station. Lots to feed our animals with. Young cautioned not to take a penny's worth of supplies.
We arrived at the missionary station of the Pawnees which has been deserted near a year by the missionaries.
At the station we found plenty of corn fodder and hay for our teams which had been put up by some of the Brothers last summer.
Prest. Young says he has no fear of the Pawnees troubling us here, but we had better be prepared lest the Sioux should try to steal horses.
The cannon is prepared and brother Tanner is drilling his men to use it until dark.
We reach the olde Pawnee misseanery post but it was evacauated to is a fine situation.
Camping at the old Missionary station having traveled sixteen miles. An abundance of hay was saved by the brethren who were here last fall.
Two horses are stolen by the Pawnees. One for Doctor Willard Richards and the other for Jesse Little.
We're camped at an old Pawnee village or missionary Station and we found plenty of hay which is very execptable
My face bad again through sleeping cold. The air [is] chilly but a very pleasant morning.
Ahh, a beautiful morning!
Some of our men have gone on horseback to seek out a fording on the Platt.
This is a place of surpassing beauty and the farms, buildings and fixtures shows much taste in the former occupants.
Riding with Young and others to look for a place to ford the Loup Fork. Looks like we'll have to make rafts to get our supplies across.
A portion of our men are engaged in examineing the different fords in the Loup Fork to find the best crossing.
Our scouts returned and reported that we would have to go about 4 miles along the river and there build a raft.
We got a late start today.
We are now leaving our camp.  We will travel about  miles to the place that Miller fordes the Loup fork of the Platt.
Tarlton Lewis to be in charge of building the raft.
Young told Case to take plows etc as govt payment. He worked for govt nearby, fired w/out pay when he became Mormon. We'll leave a letter.
We've come 5 miles looking for a fording place, and got 4 waggons over with mutch difficulty.
The wagons are prepared to ford. Luke Johnson was the first who went over, and although he had no load, it was with difficulty he got over.
Orson Pratt next with a part of his load. When he had got in about a rod his horses began to sink in some sand and they could not draw.
Moved four miles in hopes to cross the ford, but the current is too rappid and the quicksand so bad that it is very difficult crossing.
Pret. Young ordered that no more wagons should go over this way, but move up the river about a quarter of a mile and Camp untill morning.
It has been a very difficult crossing on account of the the quicksand and the swiftness of the stream.
Several small fords today. At Loup Fork now. Majority think we don't need a raft. Will try to ford without.
Visited the Government station burnt last summer by the Sioux. Crossed Plum Creek, then dragged first wagons over Ash Creek with a rope.
We had come up the Platt & Loupe fork about 150 miles throug as fine a countrey as I ever saw
We campt about 3/4 of a mile below the olde Pawnee town. I went to see it
The town stood on the bank of the river, it contained about 140 lodges last winter
when the Pawnees ware all gon on there hunt the [Sioux] came and burnt there town
The Captains of tens voted to build 2 light rafts. Loads will be carried over in the boat, and the teams with empty wagons will ford it.
traveled 5 miles to loup fork of Platte River and camped for night. 3 waggons crossed over. Bro Orson Pratt like to have drowned his horses
Camping for the night. Will attempt to build a raft to cross most of our loading and then double the teams in hopes of getting them across.
Heavy current, quicksand, much labor and dangerous getting a few wagons across. The rest will camp upstream and try tomorrow elsewhere.
I suffered an accident while watering my horse in Plum Creek. My foot slipped and my horse stepped on my instep and my breast twice.
A strong guard was set tonight on account of our nearness to the Pawnees. I was on guard the first shift. All slept with their clothes on.
Morning fine but cool. One of Phineas Young's horses was choked to death last night. This is a grevious loss.
got up early
One of Phineus Young's horses was just found dead. It fell into a hole, rope just long enough to fall in and hang. Great cause to mourn.
By request of brother Kimball, I went up to the old Indian village immediately after breakfast to take a view of it and write a description.
B Youngs horse got choked to death with the halter
we confabulated for a while what method to persue, & built 2 rafts which was to no purpose inconceyuince of Swift Water, Now we ford
Starting to empty wagon and ferry over supplies to the sandbar in the boat. Teams taken across and back, empty wagons then w/out difficulty.
Teams with four or five yoke oxen and 2 or 3 spans of horses attached to parts of loads are beginning to cross at the ford.
I am visiting the ruins of the Pawnee village. splendid but desolate. Counted 30 skulls that lay on the ground to bleach beside graves
my feelings were peculiar while—walking among the ruins. I picked up a skull bone and took to camp and showed it as a curiosity.
Finished my sketch of the Indian village. I perceived the teams crossing the river very rapidly, so I returned and found most of them over.
I prepared to wade over the river, but Jackson Redding brought me Porter Rockwell's horse to ride over. I found the current strong indeed.
By following in the same track the tracks have become packed so that the teams are moving over with more ease.
This day we crost the river, we had to double team and raftering the river.
all have crossed the River.  About 3 more miles and we'll camp for the night.
We just found that the sand packs So we raised the boxes on the last wagons and all are now crossed.
we had to go about one mile quartering up part of the distance banks, the bottom is quick sand as soon as a team stops it begins to sink.
The last wagon is over on the solid Sand bar.
We then went on about 3 miles and campt on the bank of the river.
All are safely across, which we rejoice over. Time to move on and find a place to rest with better feed and less sandy soil.
Built a raft to cross remaining wagons. Pres.Young and the brethren unloaded and passed their goods into the boat before crossing the ford.
The majority crossed without taking out anything, keeping one track, doubling their teams. The quick sand packed, becoming smooth and hard.
All the wagons and teams are safely landed on the bank on the South side of the loop fork, without any loss or accident.
The wagons started on to find a better place to Camp and feed for our teams where we can stay comfortable untill Monday and give teams rest.
All are safely over. Moving upriver for grass for our horses.
P. Rockwell discovered that there were many sun fish in the Lake. I took a couple of hooks & lines and went fishing. We had some fine sport.
At between three and four p.m. we were all safe over and felt to thank the Lord

we commence taking some of our things over in a boat that we had along but found it to be too slow a process so they come to the conclusion to put on team enough to take the wagons over without unloading[.]
Quick sand made fording difficult. I left my boots on the bank when I went into the water. L. Young, thought some one had forgotten them
Walked over to O. Pratt's wagon, and through his telescope saw Jupiter's four moons very distinct having never seen them previously.
3 miles on and setting up camp. Good feed here. We plan to stay two nights, until Monday. Indians likely watching us. Cannon and guards out.
we tried the plan and found it worked well and all got over in a short time without any accident[.] we then went on a few miles and camped south of the bank of the Loup fork
the surroundding country is as handsone as I ever saw mostly Prairie but very little timber & what thare is, is along the river bank in Spots.
The spot where it used to be so sore when I was subject to spitting blood. Dr. Willard Richards, and Elder W. Woodruff relieved me.
Shaved and changed some of my clothing. The morning very pleasant, wind West.
Today is Sunday and there will be no traveling.
Four antelope are grazing about a mile and a half away, northwest, on the opposite side of the river.
It is a beautiful and pleasant day.
We stopt and rested all day.
Elijah Newman was baptized by Tarl Lewis in the Lake for the benefit of his health.
A little cloudy and a fine breeze. The grass affords quite a bit of feed. Pres. Young is satisfied with us and our movements.
Br. Newman was afflicted with the black scurvy in his legs and has not been able to walk without sticks.
After being baptized and hands laid on him [Br. Newman] returned to his waggon without any kind of help seemingly much better.
Elijah Newman just walked into camp w/out help after Tarlton Lewis baptized him for health. Elijah has scurvy and normally walks w/ 2 canes.
A pleasant Sabbath and an interesting meeting today. All the camp appears in first rate spirtits.
A meeting at the wagon of Prest. Young, and remarks made by several, and instructions by Prest. Young.
He put then into his wagon which put me to the inconvenience of walking half a mile over a burning Prairie to the camp. Many wagons left.
I just washed out my dirty clothes.
In the evening the brethren were called by the horn and addressed by Prest. B. Young upon the principal of saving the game that we kill.
Young is counseling on not guarding as a gentile military and on hunting. 8 horses and 11 men assigned to hunting. The 12 can hunt too.
A company of hunters were selected to hunt for the company that their might be an end to every man runeing ahead with his gun to scare away the game.
Today we rest from our laibours. 8 hunters was selected to hunt on horse back for Buffalo Some 18 or 20 to hunt on foot.
Someone is sounding the alarm
2 of oure gard fired there guns on oure Left wing clos to the river and reported that Indians ware creeping close to oure line
The alarm is sounding, not the bugle. Going to see what it is.
Just endured a fright: alarm sounded. 6 Indians were trying to steal horses. Guard is strengthened & cannon ready to fire if they try again.
6 indians was indeavering to Steal horses, but fortunately disconvered & fired at by the guard, who all ways keep a good look out
Three of the guard who were stationed at the North East of the Camp discovered some Indians crawling toward the wagons.
The guards heard something rustle in the grass and first suspected they were wolves and fired at them.
Only one gun went off and six Indians sprang up and ran from within a few rods of where they stood.
The Camp was soon under arms but nothing more was seen of them--It was suposed to be [Sioux] Indians by the shape of the track in the Sand
Alarm sounded for 6 Indians that have crept into the very border of our encampment. The gard has fired upon them and they are on the run.
The guard reported that indians were near. He fired a shot, and they left.
All hands are under arms ready to repel any attack that might be made by the Indians.
We were all aroused just before daybreak by the bugle caused by 3 guards firing upon 6 indians creeping in to steal our horses.
The footsteps of the Indians can be plainly seen, where they had come down under the bank & sometimes stepped in the water.
No doubt [the Indians'] object was to steal horses. However the prompt reception they met with will show them that we keep a good watch.
about an hour before day we were alarmed by the guard that Indians were upon us. the guard fired up on them and they disappeared
Started on foot and travelled four miles, then waited for the wagons.
There is no road here, consequently, Prest. Young, Kimball, G.A. Smith, A. Lyman & others went a head on horse back to point out the road.
Going ahead with 3 others to find the best way, since there is no trail. Horses going first to tamp grass so it won't hurt the oxen's feet.
The sun is very hot & not much wind. I find it has a great tendency to make sore lips, parched up and feverish.
We travel very slow this afternoon having made only 7 miles. We crossed two sloughs or soft places though not very bad.
Traveling upriver. We lunched near an abandoned indian village and passed another. Signs of late buffalo also discovered.
Traveled 14 miles. Crossed two swampy areas. No good feed here--no new growth, and last year's is poor. No buffalo. Woolsey killed a goose.
Br. Benson's wagon unloaded, the axle taken off, brother Tanner's forge set up and a broken axle welded and fixed.
Traveled 7 hours; nineteen miles.
Bro Tanner traveled the whole day with a nearly broken shoulder of an axle. Within an hour of camp, we got the blacksmith to fix it.
We traviled about 14 miles and camped on a small run called gravel Creek. By this time timber had became very scarce.
Two horses are missing myself and others are going in search of them.
This evening about dark the Indians took two horses and made there escape.
Joseph Matthews came into Camp from seeking his horses and stated that an Indian had rode a horse off a little before.
Some brethren were dancing when an alarm sounded--Bro Little's horse is missing, and they think an Indian stole it. We'll go in pursuit.
Br Little and Br Richerds lost a horse apeare apiece that was taken by the indians
traveled 16 miles. Doct Willard Richards and Bro Little had their horses taken by the Idians. the Brethren pursued but could not get the horses
About dark, Brother Little and Dr. Richards noted that horses were missing. Search was made but they were not found.
Although aided by a clear sky and bright moon we have found them not and thus return to camp.
Back at camp. Dr. Richard's mare is also gone. A great loss. We trust this is a warning to the men to be more careful.
Went back to the old Indian village before breakfast with O.P. Rockwell, to see if any tracks of he lost horses could be found.
Four of the brethern just left to hunt for the lost horses.  The rest of us will resume our journey by striking across towards the Platt
We left the Loup fork and went South for the platt.
Resuming our course along the main Platte, as much south as we can. Several brethren heading back to attempt to find the lost horses.
Four men have gone to search for the horses, the remaining company is preparing to cross the creek.
Passing through dry, sandy, and barren country.
Come where the olde grass was burnt and green gras was again to be seen but it was too small to do mutch good, the first Sines of Buffeloo.
We have halted to refresh our teams.
Resting after 12 miles. Very green, lots of buffalo chips, but no water. Dug several 4-foot wells and got some but not enough for the teams.
Hunters have killed an Antelope. Still traveling.
Brown, Stephens and Woodruff just shot an antelope, which seems to be a cross between a deer and a goat.
The teams commenced to move again. Just as they started, J. Brown, R. Stevens and brother Woodruff all shot at an Antelope and killed him.
Started quartering for the Platt. Rockwell and others searched for the missing horses. Reached the burnt prairie which looked quite green.
Making camp for the night.
Luke Johnson shot a very large Rattlesnake and brought it back to camp for the oil. Roswel Stevens killed a hare.
Setting up camp. Johnson shot a rattlesnake that nearly bit him. Cut it open for the oil, which is supposed to be good for sore legs.
The four horseman have returned. They encountered Pawnees that fired six guns at them our men without taking any effect.
O.P. Rockwell, Mathews, Eldridge and Brown returned from hunting the lost horses. They ran great risks indeed but got safe back to camp.

Our brethren returned from the horse hunt without them--they saw 15 Indians who tried to rob them of their horses but they drawed their pistols and the Indians desisted but fired on them as our Brethern retreated
We stopt this night on a fine little creek in the open praria. Antelope was kild. this was the first game of any Size that had been killed.
Jest as we stopt a gun accidentley went off and broke a horses legg. This was the fourth hors that was lost since last friday.
One of the most valuable mares in camp was just Shot through the accidental discharge of a gun.
Those searching for the horses were nearly attacked by Indians who likely stole our horses. A loss, but our men returned safely.
Rockwell and the men returned. The horses’ trails led back to the Pawnee camp. 15 Indians attempted to steal their horses.
Just arrived at a hansom little creek about ten miles north of the Platte
Our men made for a wicket on the Loup about half a mile off. They were fired upon but our men did not return fire.
Accidental discharge of a gun as a man grabbed his coat it was under. Shot broke a horse's leg. 4th lost in as many days. Greatest loss yet.
Four men try to find the stolen horses and are ambushed by 15 Pawness, armed with guns, bows and arrows striped for fight.
The Indians come within a few feet, but realize it may cost their lives so fall back and do no damage.
At Prairie Creek, I accidentally fire a gun and the shot broke a horse leg after setting a sack of clothes on fire.

A Rifle was accidentally discharged in a wagon and the ball struck the leg of a fine mare belonging to Lewis Barney which broke the bone and rendered her entirely useless. Thus we have lost two horses within a few days by nothing but carelessness.
The gun is Brother Matthew Ivory's gun. He had put it into the wagon loaded and capped and my coat caught the hammer.
traveled 12 miles the cattle and horses suffered very much for drink
Some of the brethern shot an antelope and a hare today.
Morning fine and pleasant. No disturbances from Indians. The wind blew strong from the north East which makes it much cooler.
A horse that was accidently shot last evening was shot dead this morning to put him out of misery.
A gun accidently went off and broke the nigh fore leg of Br. Markham's horse. This makes 4 of the best horses lost within the last 4 days.
L. Johnson shot the horse dead which had her leg broke last night. Better to shoot her than leave her alone to the mercy of the Indians.
Orders early for only hunters to leave camp. Heading out now to dig out a crossing in the creek for the wagons.
Crossing prairie creek.
The brethren had to make a road down to the small creek near which we camped.
The last wagon crossed [the creek].
We have arrived at the Platte river.
Traveled 7 mi. along flat prairie with green grass and strong wild onions, then another 4 mi. along the Platte. Halting now to feed.
The country we have passed over today is the most we had beautifull I ever beheld. Continous green grass as far as the eye can see.
Continuing our journey. Wind has blown all day, kicking up dust and covering everything. The men are almost black.
We crst the Creek and went on about south about 8 miles and Came near the Platt timber. The bottom had the appearance of a vast green Sea.
It is a beautiful countrey but rather sandey.
After traveling a few more miles (18) we have camped for the night.
Camped about 1/4 mile from the timber. There is plenty of grass to fill the stock tonight. The water is also clear and cool and good tasted.
Making camp about 1/4 mile from timber. Good feed, clear water. Will have fresh antelope meat for supper.
Yesterday and today I read a book of 212 pages, as I rode along in my wagon. Traveling time of horse teams, 6 hours, distance 15 miles.
Making camp at Wood Creek, a clear stream with a gravel bottom. Traveled 16 miles today.
I do not know any thing what transpired today
Since the stock has eaten up the grass, we're moving on before breakfast to find a place for the animals to feed.
We have started before sunrise on account of getting feed for the teams.
Breakfasted on Goose and mouldy bread.
Eating breakfast after traveling 3 miles: goose Woolsey killed and bread I baked at WQ. Mouldy but doesn't hurt the taste too much.
Stopped to feed and take breakfast.
We crost wood creek. The creek runs about west and the Platt about southwest
The day is fare and pleasant
So far today have forded a stream a rod wide and traveled 10 miles. Resting and feeding by a lake. Strong wind from the south.
we just came in sight of Buffalo there was a great excitement
I am not astonished at wagons & every thing else shrinking up, for the wind is perfectly dry and parching; there is no moisture in it.
There is a white substance that seems to ooze out of the ground around here, and tastes like Salt but not so strong as common salt.
Crossing the Wood River.
We traviled this day about 16 miles. the day was verrey warm and a hevey callum arose along the line.
Followed an old trading trail, crossed a creek at a good ford, about eight yards wide, supposed to be the Wood River of Mitchels map.
Large body of beautiful level land between here and the Platt. Sufficient timber, if used carefully, for quite a large settlement.
Not a sufficient quantity of grass to sustain teams without hay. Travel time seven hours, distance eighteen miles.
18 miles today. Wind made the trip nearly suffocating from the dust. Found white substance oozing from the ground--a mild salt.
I am now watching my horses as they fill themselves with rushes on the borders of Grand Island. Traveled abut 18 miles today.
it was quite Cool through the night.
About a mile from where we camped last night, we passed a place where Indians have camped no doubt during their hunt.
We have thus far followed the Indian trail, but it is now so grown over and so old it is scarcely discernable.
Traveling today is much more pleasant--a lot of grass, buffalo chips, buffalo grass. Saw a former Indian campsite.
The wind blowing from the north tremendous strong, and clouds of dust rising from under the wagon wheels. Very cold and gloomy.
It is very cold today, the North blast has made us resort to overcoats.
A cold wind has started blowing in from the north.
Just spotted a hurd of bufalow and started out some hunters on horses
The hunters killed five big buffalo and six calves
Started up the Platte on the trail where ox teams in summer should stop over night. No wood nor water except the little we had to dig for.
Wind, high and cold from the west. Air full of haze by smoke.  Thermometer at sundown 41°. Travel time 7 hours, distance 17 miles.
After a 1 pm break, the weather turned cold and gloomy. We'll stop soon to make camp, with wagon tongues away from the wind.
The wagons are formed in an imperfect circle, in such a manner as to have all the wagon mouths [turned away] from the wind.
A soft bottom between us and the Platt has made it expedient for us to camp on the background without wood or watter.
Have sunk a well about six feet and found watter.
Far from timber, I invented a buffalo chip furnace for cooking by digging holes in the ground with a draft and way to hold pots.
For the first time we resorted to Buffaloo manure for fuel and find it better than we had expected.
the wind was north and Came brisk and very Cold. we traelied about 16 miles and Campt without timber
The camp have found a good substitute for wood in the dried buffallo dung which lies on the ground here in great plenty.
[The buffalo dung] makes a good fire when properly managed.
Tonight we camp on the open prairie without wood or water.
Coldest it's been. Each man wants an overcoat or buffalo robe. Some wrestle or dance to the fiddle to keep warm. All in good spirits.
Brother Hanson played some on his violin and some of the brethren danced to warm themselves.
traveled 20 miles and camped for the night
Breaking camp and traveling early to find feed for the teams before we eat breakfast.
Very cold indeed. There is little grass for the cattle.
Three buffalo grazing on the bluff about 6 miles distance. I could see them plainly with my glass.
We have started before breakfast.  We'll stop later when we have wood and water.
The sun is rising clear and Beautifull upon us, with it the cold chilling Blast of the North as we stay along the Platt.
Camp is eating breakfast while 3 hunters go after wild buffalo--we think there's a herd of 74 about 8 miles off.
we discovered about 50 Buffelows--oure hunters wounded one but got none. Soon after we Saw hundreds we got five olde ones & a number of calves
A herd of buffalo is in sight.
3 of our horsemen tried their skill upon a herd of buffalo. They wounded several but secured none.
4 miles. Resting by a lake. Hunters returned with reports of almost downing buffalo but one buffalo shot and two herds got away.
The hunters returned and reported that Luke Johnson shot at one and dropped him to his knees, but he rose again and ran after the herd.
Passing a long range of "dog towns," and see many of the little prairie dogs playing round their holes.
Another still larger herd [of buffalo] discovered still farther West, also at the foot of the bluffs.
This being the first day buffalo have been seen on our journey, it excited considerable interest and pleasure.
We meet some travelers at the head of Grand Island south side of river and send letters back by them
While [we] feel for the safety of the hunters, [but] a piece of fresh meat would taste good to all.
Er. Kimball rode close to [a buffalo] with his fifteen shooter and fired over his horses head. She dropped helpless and was soon dispatched.
At the report of the gun, Er. Kimball's horse sprang & flew down the bluff like lightning; his situation was precarious in the extreme.
Er. Kimball being a good horseman, he maintained his position in the saddle and soon succeeded in reigning in his horse without accident.
Another herd--this one of 200--has been spotted. Young sent 11 to give chase. Many are excited, having never seen buffalo before.
The hunters are close to the herd now. I'm eager to join in the chase to get meat from the wild animals.
Mounted my horse, borrowed Eggen's fifteen shooter. Off at a keen gallop, leaving behind those strung at a high pitch from excitement.
12-15 horsemen are giving chase to a herd of about 200 buffaloo. We are watching from our waggons as we pass along with much interest
We come to the buffalo and kill nine in a little time.
Our hunters have obtained 5 old buffalo and several calves.
The hunters killed four old ones and 6 calves. We sent out waggons and butchers to dress and bring in the game
we see thousands of Buffalo they looked magestic. the Brethren pursued them and killed four beside five calves. we had a rich repast.
Came in sight of the first buffalo we had seen. We have plenty of good meat for supper; it is much better than beef.
The total number [buffalo] killed in the first days buffalo hunt by the Camp [is] 1 Bull, 3 Cows & 6 Calves, far exceeding our best hopes.
The [buffalo] meat is cut up into quarters and distributed one quarter to each company of ten.
Travel time nine hours distance eighteen miles. We traveled quite slowly as some ox teams were weak for want of food.
we this day passed through what is Cald a Peria [prairie] dog town. we Stoped a little before son set
The meat has arrived in camp and is being equally divided among the several tens. Bro Joseph Hancock has been discovered missing.
we got in oure beef which was received with mutch joy. We had a fine feast
Moving 2 miles it being Sunday to where we can find better grazing for our teams.
the night was so cold that water in our buckets is froze half inch thick water, but the sun is  quite pleasant and warm
our Camp this morning had the appearance of a meat market. all hands were busey fixing there Beef for Cooking and drying.
The ice was near a 1/2 inch think this morning but Soon Came off warm and pleasant
Brother Hancock came into camp having killed a buffalo too late to find his way to camp last night. Men have been sent after the meat.
Sun. Thermometer at sunrise 20°. Rough road. Ravines made by rain, prairie dog holes and the buffalo licks.
The Buffalo meat Came good to us for Curtice [Curtis Lyman] and myself had lived on Corn bread water porrage for Some time
Bro Joseph Hancock killed a Buffalo and laid by it all night.
in the morning came into camp and got a team to bring in his meat but while absent the wolves had devoured the most of it
We will stay here to dry and cure the meat.
Presit. Young, [Elder] Kimball and others started out to look out a camp ground where better feed can be obtained for our stock.
On their return, [Prest. Young and Elder Kimball] said we should tarry here tomorrow & have some blacksmith work done & probably hunt some.
Buffalo lick up the saltish white deposit (saline efflorescence of Fremont) which have covered the soil thickly for the last forty miles.
Most of the men are busy taking care of their meat. I eat very heartily of buffalo meat but got rousted out very early by its effects.
We've spent the day taking care of our meat.
staid in camp until five in the afternoon then hiched up and went 2 miles on account of feed for our cattle and horses
The weather is still cold. No travel today.
The hunters are going out on foot. Tanner & Davenport are fixing their forges to do some repairing, shoeing, &c.
Prarie fires rage in different directions. I am proceeding upriver with fifteen others to see if there is sufficent feed for our horses.
travelled two miles to git feed for a our cattle and horses. the night was so cold that ice froze in our buckets again
The Camp stoped the day to do some black Smith work and let oure teams recrutt a little. It being the best place we had found
a Company of twentey hunters went out to hunt and fifteen went up the river to Se the Situation of the Countrey
After ten miles we determined there was enough grass to sustain our horses. We've seen many signs of indians.
The party who went out to look at the route returned and reported that brother Empey had discovered a large war party of Indians.
one of our company went about 1 1/2 miles beyond where we halted and has reported to us that he saw a war party in a hollow.
Orders were given to dispatch a number of the brethren on horses, well armed to warn the hunters and tell them to come to camp.
the fifteen Came back and reported that they had Seen a large Camp of indians and that they tred waylay them but oure men escape[d].
the Brethren went to hunt Buffalo but discovered a party of Indians in ambush and they returned to the camp.
Cloudy but warm in the forenoon. Strong wind and quite cool in the afternoon. A hunting party killed two antelopes and returned
Some of the brethern went on a scouting party and discovered a war party of Pawnees.
The Pawnees burnt the prairie for miles which has made feed scarce.
after discovering the Indians, the Brethren fitted up the old cannon, fired it off so that they might know we was on hand
All the hunters arrived, having got 3 antelope, and the horsemen who went after them got two [buffalo] calves, which were all brought in.
Upon our report it was ordered that the cannon be ready for immediate use and capt Thomas Tanner with his artillerymen accompany it.
staid in camp all day.
A member of a scouting party saw some Indians. We sent a party out to call in the hunters.
The scouts came in about dark and brought two calves they had killed. We fired the cannon to let the Indians know we had one.
The cannon was unlimbered and prepared for action in case it should be needed.
Wm. Smoot was thrown from a horse and his senses knocked out of him by the fall. He soon recovered and appears to have sustained no injury.
Camp called together and received instructions from president Young, especially in regard to leaving the wagons and scattering off hunting.
We have discoveredon the south side the river 3 trading waggons bound downwards. They report they are only 16 days out of Fort Laramie.
The traders think it adviseable for our company to ford the river and take the Oregon road  as the prairie is so burnt on the north side.
A council has been called and we have voted to continue on the north side and make a road for our brethren who should follow in the summer.
The wagons commenced moving and passed over the lake near its junction with the river, at which place it is bout 10-12 feet wide.
starting and travelling in plattoons on account of the Indian.
Proceeded five wagons abreast so as to be better prepared for defense should the Indians attack us.
One of the men from the wagons on the other side overtook us; they have been to Fort Laramie for furs.
Just met a trader from Fort Lara.  His company was on the other side of the river.  They had seen us and he waded across to us.
We sent letters back to our friends.
about noon we met a United States Trader and stoped in our waggons and wrote a line back to our friends
3 trading wagons passed us on the Oregon routes. We presented one of their men, Charles Beaumont with 51 letters for winter.
We have travelled to day only about 6 miles, having stopped much.
The olde grass which was short and fine by this time was Some what filled with a new groath which made tollerable fead tho not the best
a Small Compeney of traiders was passing down the outher side of the Platt. they inforamed us Side the river the grass was good
We held a short Consultation on the subject and Concluded to keep on this side, becaus it would [be] better for our brethren who would follow
Camp was called together, and after hearing the pros and cons, it was voted unanimously to keep up the north side of the Platte to Larimie.
No fresh signs of Indians except the prairie fires, near and among the bluffs. They are probably, burning it for buffalo range.
We have decided to continue on this side of the Platt for the present as we wish to establish a road independent of the gentile road for the accomodation of our families who should follow after
I went on foot about 2 miles and then stopped to count the horses, mules, oxen, &c.
Er Kimball offered me his horse to ride. I then went ahead with the horsemen.
this morning is a beautiful one and the first thing that met our eys was a herd of Buffalo they looked splendid.
Came to a very bad slough and had to bear off to the north to find a place to cross it.
Stopped to feed on a small patch of unburnt grass, having come 9 miles, course about West.
The soft praiarie has been hard wheeling and our teams fair hard for grazing.
This day we found the land more moist and Soft than we had found before. the wheels cut in considerabley in many places
We travelled on abt. half an hour and found the prairie all a blaze. Pr. Young and Kimball think it unsafe to risk the wagons near the fire.
Moderate weather today with a south wind.
The prairie is all burned bare, and the black ashes fly bad, making the brethren look more like Indians than white folks.
we had to stop becaus of the fire and smoe a head, and the wind had blown a perfict gale all day from the South. We camped Close to the river
Our hunters have killed one Buffaloo cow and a number of calves today. we made about 15 miles.
Buffalo feeding at a little distance, like tame cattle. Stopped about four p.m. by a wall of fire reaching from the river to the bluffs.
In the afternoon five calves and one cow was killed. We turned, quartering back about a mile and camped, by the Platte.
the weather is fine but the feed poor. we had to camp in an unpleasant place before night on account of fire
This day we went about 10 miles to day the campe kiled one Buffelo Cow and five calves. We had plentey. All first rate meat
Rain is nearly extinquishing our fires.
Buffalo meat is a drug in the camp. I imagine our selves in a game country. The feed is eaten completely down by buffalo
Prest. Young called to the camp and proposed to go on where we can find feed for the teams.
starting before breakfast
During the night the Lord sent a light shower of rain which has put the fire out except in one or two places...
Travelled about two miles and stopped on the unburned grass to feed.
Sun rose, clear and pleasant. Started at half past five and took the old trail. Soon passed the fire which burnt slow.
As it poor picking where we stoped we started earley and went 2 or 3 miles to a place that had not ben burned and took breakfast and bated
Saw 13 elk together, also many antelope and numerous herds of buffalo on both sides of the river.
The President gave orders that no more game should be killed untill further orders.
The president had lost his large Spy Glass while chasing the Cows from the buffalo herd a second time. He did not find it.
We have passed 5 to 10 thousand Buffaloo today and they have eaten most of the feed we had hoped for our horses.
buffalo grasing in all most everry direction. antilope in everry direction, killed 2 this fore noon.
by this time maney of the teams began to fail for want of food, We Could See the green grass on the outher side of the river
it was necessary to select a rout on the north side of the Platt for the Church to travel
if we had Crossed those who followed would loose the track and it might prove gratley to there disadvantage, so we kept on.
traveled 4 miles along the Platt River then bated our teams and travled ten milds futher.
Some think we have travelled 18, some 20 and some even 25 miles to day, but from the # of times we stopped... I feel satisfied 15 is plenty.
Large and small herds of buffalos in sight all around and on both sides of the river. No timber. It is getting scarce.
During this day we were never out of sight of large herds of buffalo
Some of our teams are beginning to fail for want of feed.
my judgement is that we have seen 8,000 Buffalo today. in fact we have not been out of sight of them all day.
the Buflow tried to git in to our drove of cows and Br Brigham and Br Heeber rode after them and had a verry hard chase
in the chase Br B lost his spiglace.
Prest Young lost his Spy glass
we camped on the bank of the river in a bad place. th bufalow come neer our camp
Cold wind from the north, this morning. Immense herd of buffalo near.
The Prest. chastised Erastus Snow for not attending to the cows yesterday causing the prest. to lose his spy glass.
President Young has called us together to give council.
Pres. Young said that thair Should be no more game killed until such time as it should be needed. for it is a Sin to waste life & flesh
Our fuel last night and this morning was buffalo dung. Waiting for an item to be fixed and our teams to fill themselves.
We started late this mor[n]ing that oure teams night have a chance to fill themselve[s.] the wind blue hevey from the north and cold
Porter Rockewell, Thomas Brown, and Joseph Mathews started back to hunt the spy glass.
Friday morning found a broken exeltree in one of the wagons put in another and started at ten oclock. drove 4 milds along the river and found no feed.
We are finally heading out after securing an axletree as feed for our horses in case we don't find better ahead.
The ground is nearly covered with Buffaloo dung and the whole country seems alive with these wild cattle.
The Buffelo are so plenty at this time that it requires a strict watch to keap them and oure Cows from running to geather
Quite a breeze. Camped in a semi-circle on the bank of the Platte. Distance twenty miles. Feed poor and the teams failing.
th plains are lined with bufalow. I hav no dout but I hav seen to day at one sight more than 2 two thousand at one glance of the eye.
Porter and the others returned having found the spy glass, which was a source of joy to all the brethren.
we camped about 4 o clock in a beautful place found some grass for our teams.
the bufalow are so tame that we are troubled to keep them a way from ourr catle. we had to stop our teams once to let them pas.
We traveled about 11 miles today. We were obliged to camp upon a perfectly barren Spot on the river bank.
Hariet  has not injoyed the day. she has bin verry sick with the teeth ache. I laid hans on her when we stoped and she got beter
During this day we traveled about 19 miles in which time we beheld nothing but one continual string of buffalo,
I have been very sick all day with the bowel complaint and have suffered much.
Setting up camp on the bank of the Platte.
the Brotherin all seem in good sperits. it has bin a day long to be remembered on the acount of the romantick seens that has transpired.
a s young Buflow caf came in to camp which seemed determined to stay with us.
yesterday we found one on the peraria and we left it and before we got out of sigt alarg woolf came upon it and caried it off. aperintly with mutch eas but it looked verry cruel
Travelled 8 miles. Camped in a circle on the Platte. Buffalo very plentiful, passing continually, to and from the river to drink.
Br little is now talking about his family. his helth is improving. we had to camp where the feed was very short and poor
This is the first chastisment I have had since I have been in this church; nearly 15 years; and I hope it may last me 15 years to come.
The feed is gitting poor on the account of the continuial hurds of Buffalow. some of our teems are giving out
I recieved a regular built dressing from Pres. B. Young after he lost a spyglass while chasing after cattle I was in charge of.
This day we traviled about 9 miles and Camped near the river by a Slue.
Porter Rockwell with 2 others went back and found Br Bs glass.
Porter Rockwell went back to find Pres. Young's spyglass. Returned having found it.
Brother Erastus Snow received a severe reprimand from Brigham for not attending to his duty when it was his turn to drive the cows and for trying to excuse himself[
verry little air stirring. a warm plesant day hitching up our teams to get underway.  our direction N.W.
The prairies on both sides of the river are litterally black with buffallo.
A fine warm morning the grass is entirely eat down by the Buffelo So that our teams can scarsley subsist
There are thousands of buffalo on both sides of the river.
it is a warm and pleasant day. we are stoped  on the bank of the platte, and the ground on both sides of the river is covered with Buffalow
I am Standing on my waggon & see more than 10,000 Buffalo. The Plain is purfectly black with them on both sides of the river
I have counted the revolutions of a wagon wheel to tell the exact distance we have travelled... this method is somewhat tedious.
I have repeatedly suggested a plan of fixing machinery to a wagon wheel to tell the exact distance we travel in a day.
There are countless numbers of buffaloes on both sides of the Platte, so thick that the ground appeared black with them.
The grass is eaten, and dung is plentiful: in fact and the bottom today looks like an old yankee pasture that needs turning over.
Two horses commenced running with the buffalo. Grover and J. Brown had quite a race on their horses to get them back.
Today we traveled 11 miles.
We proceeded on 3.5 miles, going a little round some of the bluffs untill we turned down on a low bottom and very sandy.
I went about 3/4 of a mile below to the river, and washed my socks, towel and handkerchief as well as I could in cold water without soap.
