I then stripped my clothes off and washed from head to foot, which has made me feel much more comfortable, for I was covered with dust.
We went this about 3 1/2 miles to git better range but found a Sandey, naked Countrey. the are hard times on teams but we hope for the better
this morning traveled 4 miles and camped for the day.
After only traveling 4 miles, we have stopped opposite a small Island of cotten woods to feed our teams. We will tarry here over Sunday.
Rolled on 7 miles and passed the bluffs by going down the back, and keeping up on the sand beach.Sunday
According to my calculations, we are now 300 miles from Winter quarters lacking a few rods.
We are placing a written history of our journing in a box secured to a tall post for the benefit of our brethren who should follow.
I was very sick all day in consequence of taking the scent of a dead Bufalo. there is a great many dies of poverty.
Lorenzo Young gave me an emetic and I got better.
It is a lonesome country to me to travel through, there is no flowers and little or no timber
Camp called together; remarks made, and rules read. The bottom is one mile wide. Soil sandy. Feed eat out.
I spent the afternoon reading and writing in Elder Kimball's journal.
This morning is cool. We are just getting started.
After traveling 2 miles we crossed a small creek which Er. Kimball named "Skunk creek."
The brethren at the head of the Camp discovered a strange horse, alone in the prairie. Porter and T. Brown gave chase to try to catch it.
it is now warm and pleasant. we travil along verry agreeable all in union
At the Creek four miles back some of the brethren shot a buffalo... the meat is said to be good and the fattest we have had.
A board was put up on a stake and written on it, "look in this and you will find a letter." The letter was put there for the next company.
On the other side of the above named board was written "316 miles from Winter Quarters, westward bound, Pioneers."
Feed has been improveing a little through the day and the Buffaloo not so plenty and we are not a little glad now account of it.
Brother Kimball says that angels surround the camp and when a faithful servant of God was in danger swift messengers would be sent.
Crossing a small stream.
We are reproofed for all the wasted game. he says the spirit that was manifest would kill and waste all the game on the plains.
He says that if a man will not transgress any laws he will be as free as the water that runs and no blessings will be witheld from him.
The grass evidently springs later the farther west we travel.
Rode over unburnt grass; no wagon track but our own. Plenty of buffalo in sight, plenty of brouse grass and wood, and water plentiful.
At this place we put up a post with a box on it and a letter in the box for the next Camp. 316 miles from winter quarters.
We feast upon a fat cow and a fine deer and are setting camp near the north shore. We have traveled about 10 miles today.
traveled ten miles.
Bro Phineas Young killed a Buffalo, an atntelope, and shot a Duck this day. the feed is poor our cattle cannot travel but little in a day.
we are saving Buffalo wool. Bro Luke Johnson was the first one that started it
Blacksmithing going on. Rolled on and camped in a circle about half a mile from water. No wood. Buffalo chips for fuel. A few buffalo seen.
Went with a number of the brethren who were going to dig some wolves out of a hole about a quarter of a mile from camp.
[The brethren] dug out 4 [wolves] and brought them alive to camp. They are probably 6 or 8 weeks old and... very vicious.
Passed over a creek of clear water, but cannot be very good in consequence of so many dead buffalo laying in it.
The brethren dug two wells, and about 4 feet deep found plenty of good water.
Distance 9 miles. The bottom on the south begins to widen again and the bluffs slope and become smoother with more grass on them.
We are stoped for our teems to feed as we have found beter feed than we have had for several days
Today we found but little grass for our teams. We have past fue Buffelo, it appeared that they had eat all the grass and left the place.
The feed is so short and teams so weak we are unable to travel but a small portion of the day. We have traveled about 8 miles.
The weather is still cool today.
the weather is fine we traveled 8 miles and camped about 3 oclock in an unpleasant place for the teams were tired and began to lag
Bro. Appleton Harmon is working at the machinery for the wagon, to tell the distance we travel; expects to have it in operation tomorrow.
We have passed over vast beds of salt, or rather dust with a salt taste. It looks something like dirty flour.
There are many buffalo carcasses left by the indians who only take the hide, tongue, marrow bones and here and there a choice cut of meat.
The hunters have seen many dead buffalo between here and the bluff with hides off and tongues taken out; Indians here very recently.
the mornings and eavenings are verry cool and the middle of the day is warm and pleasant
Heavy clouds rising in the West and North West, and a fair prospect for some rain which is much needed.
Soil good and grass much better than it has been. Width of bottom from 1 to 3 miles. Elevation of bluffs from 1 to 150 feet. 12 miles.
Camped in a circle near a recently vacated Indian camp (probably Sioux). They had left a good many old moccasins.
we went 12 miles and camped it was a fine warm day.
We have traveled about 22 miles in the last two days.
we have a southeast wind the dust is troublesom. traveled 8 miles and stopped to bate our teams then came on 4 miles camped for the night
We have traveled 12 miles today and have had a warm South wind and good roads
This morning cold and cloudy, cold enough for overcoats and buffalo robes.
Some feelings are manifested this morning between brothers Thomas Tanner and Aaron Farr...
...on account of the former taking the latter prisoner and putting him under a guard part of the night.
The wind blue verrey colde from the east. The weather changes almost every day and it makes it very disagreable. we came 10 miles.
We are crossing the largest stream we have seen since we left the Loup Fork. It is a quick sand Bottom full and hard as the Loup Fork.
We just crossed a large stream where the bluff came to the river.
cold and unpleasant but find better feed for our cattle this morning. shot 2 ducks, traveled 12 miles and camped for the night.
High north east wind. Crossed the junction of a small run and Bluff creek, about 10 rods wide: supposed to be the rawhide of the traders
Making camp at the mouth of stream the President named Junction Bluff River. Horsemen are being sent to search the best way through ahead.
This evening is verrey colde--over Coats and mittens were used with pleasure
made a lively fire of Buffalo chips, made a dish of coffee, fried cakes and had a luxurious meal. at the junction Bluffs of the Platt River
We are scarcely comfortable around the fires with Top coats for a sudden change in the weather.
Colde east wind with a thunder Shouers from the south west. The bluffs Came down to the river a little ahead
I was a guard last night and it was far from being a warm birth but the weather seems to be moderating.
It is a very cold morning.
The dark clouds having approached nearer it commenced raining pretty heavy, accompanied with lightning and thunder.
we had to go round through the bluffs about fore miles, we found a verrey good pas[s]age through. bluff Countrey is very broaken and sandey
had a thunder shower for the first since we started on our journey. started at 11 and traveled 4 miles and stopped to bate them.
We have had several slight showers which seem truly reviveing to this thirsty land. We've found a good route through the sand hills.
Looks like rain and thunders. we are now where there is no wood and we have to use Buffalow dung for fuel and for cooking.
The feed for our team grows much better, and on one of these high sand bluffs I saw a large bed of flowers, not unlike the violet, and very rich.
I discover that brother Appleton Harmon is trying to have it understood that he invented the machinery to tell the distance we travel...
...which makes me think less of him than I formerly did. He is not the inventor of it, by a long way...
...but he has made the machinery, after being told how to do it.
We traveled about 8 miles and think it best that our teams enjoy the benefit of the good feed we found here Else we should travel farther.
Narrow bottom wound among the hills a few miles to a point 1 ? miles above our camp where the bluffs meet the river. Quite bold for ? mile
Not a tree and hardly a bush in sight. Bluffs very sandy but still afford good pasture. Meat brought in next morning in pretty good order.
Rain. It is so cold that the horses shake with the cold.
killed a duck traveled 3 miles and came to mountains of Bluffs that we were obliged to cross. we accordingly camped for the night
there was 2 antelope and 1 Buffalo killed in camp to day
This morning is very cloudy and cold, more like a January morning than a May morning.
is a cold and windy day with some rain
It commenced raining again and looks like for rain all day.
Cloudy, cool. Quite a shower at breakfast time. Rolled over the low hills; the roads being very sandy and crooked.
cold and rainy this morning  we are well supplied with a variety of fresh meat such as Buffalo, antelope, Ducks and geese and so on.
crossed the Bluffs which was tedious on account of the sand.
we have now stopped on account of the rain and a good place to bate.
Our chief dependence for fuel is dry buffalo dung, which abounds every where, but the rain has injured it some for burning.
we took a bite of refreshment and started on again traveled 4 miles and camped.
wind north verey cold, raind a little, over Coats, buffelo robes & mittens are all in fashion now, we had to pas over the Bluffs again
It is still so cold and there is a little rain falling.
We have traveled 7 miles & camped for Sunday; about 2 1/2 miles through the sand hills. Sand deep and very heavy wheeling.
to day we past through a bluff that the wind had blown in heaps and blown holes in the ground from 3 to 5 feet deep and several rods long
It has been showery today nearly cold enough for Snow.
we took the Revenue Cuter and went in piersuit of wood as the Buffolo Chips were rather wet. found some by going /2 mile
Rolled in and camped in a circle about half a mile from the Fork. O. P. Rockwell killed a bull. Grass good. Distance seven miles.
Today is Sunday.  We will not be traveling today.
I have not been well for the last three days, but feel better today.
Eric Glines killed an antelope near the Camp which on being opened we found to contain two large young ones.
we remain in camp to day baked and we pre pared for the weeks travil. mrs yoing is verry sick from fertuege.
the bufalow are so tame that they come all most in to camp. the boys shot some.
Br glinds shot a buffalo. the ball loged in the hart but the bufalow ran 20 or 30 rods, turned round to fight. bufalow soon fel ded.
A cold windy and disagreeable day. it's Sunday and we are lying by. we have no wood and the Buffalow dung is so damp it does not burn well
Cleared off pleasant and more warm Stopt all day. The Platt River is wide. Shale water, full of Iselands.
The Sky was overcast and wind blew cold but in the middle of the day it cleard up warm and pleasant.
Time for a meeting. All appear in fine spirits
E. Glines killed a bull and an antelope with two young ones. Camped, assembled for meeting. Remarks by Heber C. Kimball and others.
I have prepared another board to put up here, on which the distance from Winter Quarters is marked at 356 3/4 miles.
ameeting in the afternoon, all seemed to feel well in sperit and wer united in feeling the same intns to go ahead. the Lord is with us,
Dug 4 wells. The water is shallow and rusty. Plenty of buffalo all the time.
After supper Er. Whipple made me a present of a half a candle made from buffalo tallow, by the light of which I continue this journal.
travled twelve milds and ?. hunters kiled 4 bufalow one antelope. E Lsworth kiled 3 ducks and gave them to/us and Br Stphens a young deer
Dr. Richards left another letter on the Camp ground for the benefit of the next company.
The letter is secured from the weather by a wooden case, and placed so that the brethren can hardly miss finding it.
There are very many small Lizards, about 4-5 inches long from nose to the end of the tail, which is 1 1/2 inches long.
Starting out for the day. Sand hills ahead.
Measured distances by A.M. Harmon’s roadometer since the 12th. Put in operation with 1 wheel for 1 mile. Today he added a 10-mile wheel.
Moderate weather today.
Just stoped to bate the animals. We sent a wagon to bring in a buffalow that one of the hunters has killed
One of President Young's horses mired down in a soft slough. A number of men soon collected and with a rope dragged it out.
Several spring fountains coming out at the foot of the Bluffs made it soft wheeling and many marshy places.
Fine warm day. we had to cros the bluffs about 2 miles and then struck the bottom again. we crost a number of fine Spring rivers.
Quartered where the bluffs came down quite bold; with a good number of small cedar trees among them. Rock is apparent for the first time.
3 bulls and 2 antelopes were killed and brought in. Dug three or four wells, about four feet deep. Water good. Distance, 12 ? mile
we are camped for the night and formed in a circle as is our custom of camping. feed is giting verry good and our teems are improveing
traveled 12 3/4 miles. The hunters killed 4 Buffaloo and some small game which detained the camp some to secure the meat.
We went 12 3/4 miles and camped. the feed is gitting mutch better.
we camped by onthe praroe hariet has had a very sick day
The Prest. called the Captains of tens to his wagons and gave them a pretty severe lecture.
[Young] said God has given us a commandment that we should not waste meat, nor take life unless it is needful.
Captains of ten called together and the camp and horsemen especially received a lecture from Prest. B. Young.
Prest. Young is giving some sharp admonishments to some for being wasteful of flesh and to the hunters for killing more than we needed.
horsemen are also being taken to task for takeing so little interest in looking out our roads.
The officers have been admonished by Prest. Young for neglecting to enforce the rules of the camp upon their men.
We kept in the valley all day. warm day. Some soft roads. we have not sean a grove of timber for some dayes. went 15 3/4 miles this day.
Rattlesnake Creek was so named [because] as Prest. Young rode up to the banks, his horse stepped within a foot of a very large Rattle Snake.
Nooning
This stream is very crooked and seems to run from the bluffs to the river in a perfect serpentine or zig zag direction.
we begin to find for the first time ledges of rock in the bluff on both sides the river.
he men found A large seed tree. was the furst tree we had found in more than one hundred milds. they found A n Indian cofin in the top of it.
examining the cofin found bones of A child wraped in scins to secure it from birds of pray. with the bones A spoon made of horn and a ball
Camped on the west bank of a pretty clear Eagle Run, two or three yards wide. Water clear. Feed poor. Distance 15 3/4 miles.
Went with Elder O. Pratt to Dr. Richards' wagon to enter into arrangements for making a map of our route.
We traveled about 26 miles today and yesterday.
Col. Markham called the Camp together to tell the brethren their duty, in regard to traveling, guarding teams, and standing guard
we traviled 15 miles crosed two creeks
Started early to find better feed. Crossed a small run and turned animals out. Grass tolerably good.
It has rained a little most of the night, and still looks gloomy, cloudy, and like for a rainy day.
Crossed a stream about 20 feet wide, not very deep, neither very good to cross.
Arrived at the foot of he bluffs, and began to ascend without doubling teams.
Crossed another run. Sand bluffs rise along the water for about ? mile. Rain hard at times. Hard pulling, so we stopped.
Rained some in the night. rainey a little this morning. We soon had to arise the bluffs again it was the hardest whealling that we had found
It is raining slightly.
Passed stand of cedars. One had a young indian laid on its top covered in a buffalo hide with his bowl and spoon, and a small bag or pouch.
commenced raining and continued a Colde rainey day. we traviled about 8 1/2 miles and campt--The sight of a tree is out of the question.
The rain still continues to pour down heavy, and this has been the most uncomfortable day we have had and the hardest on our teams.
wheels have rolled in the sand nearly to the hub. It's rained gently nearly all day; winds in the North.
Started again at 3 and rolled on 2 miles and then camped.
We made 8 miles today.
Rainy day. Traveled 8 miles this day.
We started out again but had not travelled over a quarter of a mile before the Roadometer gave way.
[The Roadometer] broke on account of the rain yesterday having caused the wood to swell and stick fast.
Halted to feed, having travelled 7 3/4 miles over tolerable good road.
On the opposite side the river the bluffs project near its banks. They are rocky and almost perpendicular, beautified by groves of Cedar.
We just arrived oppososite the spot where the Oregon Rd. comes over to the north fork where there is a small grove of ash called Ash Hollow.
Cloudey cool day. we Came the place where the Oregan trail Strikes the South Side of the north fork, it is at ash holler
We all feel anxious to ascertain the fact whether this is Ash Hollow or not, for, if it is the Oregon Trail strikes the river at this place.
We have had rather a good chance to make as good a trail as 73 teams of cows and 143 men would make.
One of the brethren killed a large Rattlesnake within a rod of the road made by the wagons, and on the side where the cows travel.
Several very small islands scattered along the way. 4 men went in a boat and found the Oregon trail, or road to come on the South Fork.
crossing the mouth of a stream about the same size and character as the large one and camped upon the night of the 13th
I have seen several kinds of herbs growing to day which appear new to me. One looks like penny royal, smells almost like it, but taste hot.
Stopped opposite Casele [Castle] Bluffs, just eight miles from "Ash Hollow" and a half a mile from the river. Distance 15 ? miles.
by the Mechanical genius of Milo Harmon we have the distance counted off through a Machine turned by the revolution of the wagon wheels
We gethered  plenty of drift wood for fuel a long the beach.
I put up a guide board at this place with the following inscriptions on it: "From Winter Quarters 409 miles."
A book of distances was put up in camp. The hills are retreating. Width of bottom from 3-4 miles. South side no bottom. 3-4 deer seen.
Finally a beautiful day!
Prest. Young & Kimball rode forward to pick the road, and near this place they saw a nest of wolves, caught and killed two with sticks.
Halting for dinner after traveling 7 3/4 miles. We see movement in the distance Pres Young and I will go see what it is.
The movement is wolves--now running away. Grabbed a young one by the tail. Young's holding it while I kill it with a stick to the head.
Went a little further. Just chased and killed another wolf with my whipstick. The rest escaped.
Spring is about three weeks earlier later here than in the same latitude on the Missouri river.
We saw about a mile this side the foot of the bluffs a very large bone almost petrified into stone...
Most of the bretheren believe [the bone] to be the shoulder bone of a mammoth, and is very large indeed.
Cleared off more pleasant and warm. went 15 miles, a little before we campt we saw som 8 indians, one came to us.
A portion of the leg bone of a very large animal was petrified and weighed twenty seven pounds. It was found by the roadside.
they found A bone wich moshured 14 inches A cross the end of it. we found som ratle snakes the furst we hav seen
Found a large bone that looks nearly petrified. Many in the company think it might be a shoulder bone from a mammoth.
Done traveling for the day.
Wm Claton put up a guide board with the following inscription on it, From Winter Quarters 409 ms,
Er Kimball rode up and stopped the forward teams till the last ones got nearer saying that some Indians had come down from the bluffs.
We were just met by and Indian and his Squaw of the Sioux tribe.  They belonged to a hunting party in the neighborhood.
Sioux watching us. They have nice clothes and horses, surely stolen from travelers. Camp will be a tight circle, 2 entrances for horses.
Two Soux Indians are approaching. Others have been seen through the spy glasses. There is undoubtedly a hunting party not far from us.
Two Indians came nearer, a man and his squaw... represented by signs that they were Sioux and that a party of them are now on the bluffs.
an indian came to us. he was a Sioux, well dressed and appeared verrey friendly. This was the first we had sean four a long time.
an indian and his squaws came to us, stayed a few minutes and went back to the bluff
Stopped the line of march at half past five in view of our fast horsemen and two Sioux.
Lorenzo Young just brought us supper: 2 very large ducks killed with one shot with his rifle.
We are near a mile from water and the brethren have to dig wells to obtain a supply for cooking.
thare was two sem Indians came to us just as we camped tonight
Morning beautiful, warm, and no wind. We have not been disturbed by the Indians; all is peace in the camp.
Yesterday we have found a large bone supposed to be out of the foreleg of a mammoth. it weighs 27 pounds.
We buried the bone and left it with a description of it upon a board put up at its grave for other parties to inspect.
Porter Rockwell came in and said he had been on the high bluff... and had seen the Rock called Chimney rock from it.
Although my feet were blistered and very sore I will take my telescope and go on the bluff to ascertain whether the rock could be seen.
Resting after 7 1/4 miles. P Rockwell arrived, said that Chimney Rock isn't far away. Elder Clayton is going to see it with his telescope.
We have discovered through the telescope what is commonly called chimney Rock which seems about 20 miles ahead of us on the South side the river.
I started out alone [to climb the bluff and look for Chimney Rock].
Clayton back from the bluff overlooking Chimney Rock; engraved his name. Says it should be called Frogs Head Bluff from the shape of a stone
At a distance of about 20 miles I could see "Chimney Rock" very plain with the naked eye... resembles the large factory chimneys in England.
Weather good. we Came to the bluffs again, where they joined to the river. We had to finde a pass.
I turned to gaze on the romantic scenery above and [saw] a large rock... which very much resembled a frogs head of immense size.
Points of the Oregon road visible occasionally. Pulled over gravel beds for 4 ? miles. Wound around and over hills for about 3 miles.
Terrible wind and storm coming. Lightning and thunder to the SE.
The bluffs at this place Seamed to have been hove up in the utmost conf[u]sion, rocks, gravil and sand jist as it hapned.
We have noticed to day a great many petrified bones, some very large, all turned into Solid, hard stone.
The storm passed with a only few drops and moved east.
The scene after the storm is sublime. Reminds one of the goodness & majesty of the governor of the universe, the beauty of the his works.
We soon struck the bottoms again. and Camped
I saw a young Eagle taken out of its nest on one of these high bluffs, by George R. Grant and Orson Whitney.
George R. Grant and Orson Whitney took a young eagle from a nest, abt 4-6 wks old. Brethren plan to keep it. Should be big full grown.
Some of the brethren have discovered a cave, and one went into it a little distance but being very dark he did not venture far.
Passed Bluff Ruins as called by the Prest. from their resemblance to old fortification, with their turrets, towers, walls etc.
Caused by collapse of the Morley fortification. Distance 15 ? miles. Granite, quartz, greenstone etc., a great variety of beautiful flint.
yesterday as we was traviling a long we found a pease of a bone that had been the shoulder blade of some animal supposed to be the mammoth.
it was 18 inches long 12 inches wide at one end. we found a leg bone 18 inches long. bones ware petrefied as hard as a stone and ware heavy
Dr. Richards names these bluffs "bluff ruins," from their appearance being that of the ruins of Castles, Cities, &c.
an Indian dog Came to us last evening but he is verry wild & Shy & has traveld with us to day
The evening was spent very joyfully by most...  it being very pleasant and moonlight. A number danced till the bugle sounded for bed.
We have one man in Camp who is entitled to the credit of being more even tempered than any of the others, and that is father Chamberlain.
[Chamberlain] is invariably cross and quarrelsome, but the brethren all take it as a joke and he makes considerable amusement for the Camp.
the Lord delivered us tonight from A dredful thunder storm. it thundred and lightned for 2 ours. the wind blew hard and it looked dismall
to our surprise and joy the clouds seemed to part and the rain and wind went on both sides of us and did not disturb us
Br. Egan commenced washing very early on the banks of the river. He kindly volunteered to wash my dirty clothes which I accepted as a favor.
Today is a warm Sunday.  We will not travel today.
Standing on the bluffs with many brethren. O. Pratt measured the height w/ a barometer. Writing our names on a buffalo head to leave here.
meeting is appointed at 11 o clock as is our our turn to have meeting evry sabath.
I borrowed Wm. Claton's spy glass & am going to go look around.
Took time to survey the area. The Bluffs and hills to the North East of us are picturesque and Romantic in the extreme.
On our return from the bluffs, found Nathaniel Fairbanks ill from a rattlesnake bite. Must be a den of them nearby; we've killed many.
Nathaniel Fairbanks was bitten by a rattlesnake and was quite sick after it. Camp assembling for meeting
N. Fairbanks came into camp having been bit in the leg by a rattlesnake. He said that 2 min after he was bit his tongue began to feel numb.
The brethren immediately applied tobacco juice and leaves, also turpentine, and bound tobacco on his leg which was considerably swollen.
We laid hands on [Fairbanks] and L Johnson administered a dose of Lobelia in number six, after... a strong drink of alcohol and water.
[Fairbanks] complains much of sickness in his stomach and dimness in his eyes. He appears to be in much pain.
Sitting in meeting. Erastus Snow spoke, now Pres Young. He wants to teach doctrine about ordinances but can't until we have a temple.
At Ancient Bluff Ruins, the president is preaching that we are creating character for eternity and have been since obtaining the gospel.
A man of quick thought and deep meditation will lay hold and get ahead and grow in the gospel quicker than one of less perseverance
The winds are shifting, blowing cold from the North. Storm coming.
Having an interesting meeting with excellent instructions from Prest. B. Young.
If the saints had obeyed  and let the authorites go on ahead left the main camp there could have been 200 men here last year as easy as now
Receiving good counsel, especially to use what we have and stop asking for more when we haven't yet treasured up what we've been given.
E. Snow spoke then President advanced many excellent ideas. More remarks by Geo. A. Smith and some other brethren.
the weather is fine we are in sight of chimney Rock are in hopes to reach Fort Laramee this weeks
Rain began hard at 1 p.m. and continued until ten The wind blew through the night. A board with a letter plugged on it put up.
The buffalo gnat bites us very severely. Their bite is very poisonous; although they are extremely small... they punish a person very much.
Brother Fairbanks has been bit upon the leg by a rattlesnake. He is quite sick.
Brother Fairbanks and some of the other brethern been teasing a snake to make it mad and it was not a half an hour before he was bit by another snake of the same species.
Elder Clayton and I went out to review my journal and pray. Wind kicked up and took my hat. Chasing after it now--have run near 1/2 mile.
The wind blew a perfect gale and continued until seven, when it commenced to rain very heavy, large drops descending.
some indians just came to camp. They are taking supper with porter rockwell. they are Sioux
We lay bye this day, it was verrey warm untill nearley night when the wind came in a short time, it began blow and rain and was extremely cold
we are camped on A sand rig neer the most romantick bluffs I ever saw
Big but short storm is over. Going to give a priesthood blessing to Bro. Fairbanks w/ Pres Young and Elder Benson.
I am busily engaged baking bread
my health is poor yet I feel that the Lord has blessed me abundantly. I have not had anything of my old disease since I left winter Quarters.
[Fairbanks] seems considerably better. This evening, Pr Young, Kimball, and Benson laid hands on him and he seemed much better afterwards.
the atmosphere is dark and gloomy. we are havng a tremendous shower accompanied with thunder and lightning
It's a cold night. Wind, rain and some hail.
Brother Fairbamks got bit by a rattlesnake which made him very sick, but he recovered.
I lay awake most of the night, towards morning I dreamed about my family and that my children were in fine fun and glee.
Still snowing a little.
Continued our journey, 10 miles.
the morning is cold and winday
It was so Cold that we could hardley keep comfertable with over Coats and mittens on. it snowed a little. we went on
Two Soux have approached our camp, indicating that a larger group of them are camped nearby. Traveled ten miles so far today.
2 Indians approaching now that we've stopped to feed--likely to get the half dog/half wolf that's been following us.
cloudy and cold. started at 8 traveled 10 miles and stoped to bate in a beautiful place across the River
Halted to feed. While we were resting, two Indians came to Camp, their object evidently to get the dog which has followed us to this place.
We again proceeded and travelled 'til 6:00 a distance of 6.5 miles.
Several of the horse teams gave out and they are evidently failing, but the oxen are gaining daily.
a little to the right of us we can see something that resembles a stately courthouse. I presume it is a Rock
Discovered a party of Indians on the opposite side of the river, moving west. Some of the brethren went to meet them carrying a white flag.
When the Indians saw the flag, some of them began to sing, and their chief held up a US flag. Their object was to obtain something to eat.
A number of [Indians] came to the Camp and were conducted round by Cols. Markham and Rockwood. They are well-dressed and very noble-looking.
Circling the wagons for the night. about 30 Soux Indians are approaching.
A group of 35 Sioux are touring the camp. They carried a US flag across the river to show peace and wanted food.
The Sioux are well-dressed and as clean as any white man--nice moccasins with beads, etc. They like the cannon and telescope.
These indians are dressed in their richest costum and by all odds the most cleanly, orderly & best appearing of any Indians we have seen west of the Missouri river.
The chief and his squaw signified a wish to abide with our camp tonight. The brethren fixed up a tent for them to sleep under.
Some of the brethren traded horses with the Sioux and bought some Peltry Moccasins and other trinkets.
35 Dakota visited our camp. Very friendly, clean, well dressed and behaved. They had a U.S. flag and 2 letters of recommendation.
One- “O Washtecha ow le belle journec who understood four languages and was a good pilot and a good indian, etc.” signed P.D. Papin.
The other was for Brave Bear, “a good hunter and robe dresser,” but not signed.
The indians are recrossing the river apparently in high Glee.
A party of 35 Sioux Indians crossed the river to our camp to visit us
They are very friendly.
Some of the the brethern traded with them for ponies, robes, maccasina and so forth.
The old chief amused himself very much by looking at the moon through a telescope for as much as 20 minutes.
Retiring for the night, realizing that the Lord is good to us, and His mercies are over us all the day, for which we feel to praise Him.
Br. Fairbanks is much better this evening.
were visited by a party of the Sou Indian, their chief was among them. they look intelegent and appear friendly.
I have been writing in Er. Kimball's journal since dark, and have but little chance to write as much as I want in my own and his both.
Met 30 Sioux yesterday. They all wiched to come into camp so we gave them supper. they remained all night, but were good & stole nothing.
The Indians have returned on their ponies, hoping for food again. They seem pleasant and cheerful and enjoy looking at our camp.
Most of the Indians, men, women, and children came early on their ponies and marched round, mostly trying to obtain something to eat.
plesant but tolerably cool, we are again visited by our friends the Sioux.  Col Markam traded a mule for a pony and we are now starting out
Quite a frost, clear and mild. The Indians all came into our camp and stopped till we started. They are a good size and very good looking.
moste of the Indians and females Came to see and traid with us some Horses were swaped and a number of traids made.
We proceeded onward. After we started, the Indians left us and went over the river.
They were good looking and gentealey behaved people. They ware dressed neat and clean and in the highus stile of Indian habbit
The Sioux are in camp this morning. we gave them Breakfas. They stayed with us untill we started. some little traiding was done.
They appeared to posses as noble a spirit as ever animated the human brest.
Stopped already, as we found good feed for the animals. The horses are failing and need as much as they can get. Oxen and mules are fine.
Professor Pratt reports that we are in Lat. N. 41 - 42' - 46".
Barometrical height above 3371 feet and the average rise per mile since the Junction of the river has been 5 feet 6 in 9/10.
We can distinguish objects more clearly and at a much greater distance then we could in the east on account of the difference in the atmosphere.
What a warm day.
Hunter killed an antelope and is diving it among the captains of 10. Not much game lately except antelope and hares. No buffalo at all.
I am unwell. Have the Rheumatism in shoulders & back & toothake. Staying in the carriage, reading Hastings account of calafornia.
We have camped on  avery wet spot, but he feed being poor where it was drier, it was decided to stay for the benefit of the teams.
Traveled 12 miles. Bottom up to six miles wide. Camped in a circle about four miles E.N.E from Chimney rock, composed of Marley clay
Barometer calculation, by Prof. Orson Pratt at our last nights camp, height above ocean 3371 feet and 686 feet above the junction.
We traveled 12 miles today.
Chimney rock is in full view off us & is assertained to be 3 ms in an Air line. S. W.
Chimney Rock is about 3 miles distant from it. We have traveled about 36 miles since we first discovered it.
Porter Rockwell killed 2 Antelope
Many of the men are dancing until the bedtime bugle sounds at 9. We're within 5 miles of Chimney Rock now.
some verry wet hard traviling. traviled 22 miles and camped for night
Chimney Rock shows very plain, and appears not more than two miles distance, but is no doubt 5 miles distance or over.
The rocks or mounds through this section have a Singular appearance maney of them stand disconnected with the bluffs
The chimney can be seen 20 or 30 miles. This day we went 12 1/2 miles and campt. We had not fuell sufficient to do oure cooking with.
Markham's pony struck in the legs when the whipple tree unhitched from the neap of the wagon tongue. He's galloping off toward the wagons.
The dogs are meeting the pony and driving it back through the lines. Causing confusion with teams running off the road, but no one's hurt.
passing by the chimney rock wich is on the south side. the hunters killed 4 antelopes to day
we passed the chimney rock. It is Situated on the South side of the river.
we are exactely North of chimney rock & 3 ms distant. we're halting for dinner
Found good feed for the animals. Three miles from Chimney Rock. Pratt determined it is 250 high from the base.
We are passing the Peak called Chimney Rock in the south side of the river.
Started at eight a.m. and stopped at twelve; making seven and one forth miles this morning. Four antelopes killed.
It is very warm today.
we set a hen and think of trying our luck in raising chickens while traveling.
4 antilope killed today & destributed through the camp
Made five miles this afternoon. Our campe is nearly opposite Terrace Bluffs of morely clay constantly wasting away.
still traveling through a desolate and barren country, not a tree or srub to be seen.
my eyes are weary of seeing a barren prairie. I am fond of variety
Traveled only 12 1/2 miles today. Have had very good road and found better feed tonight than we have we have had for some days past.
C Murray put his baby eagle under Billings' wagon for the night. Some men just ran the wagon back--over the eagle's head, killing it dead.
Ellen Sanders fell asleep in her wagon with a candle burning that caught fire. I just came upon it with much smoke and blew it out.
Looking at the Sanders wagon. The rib is completely burnt. Wagon has a hole straight through. A miracle the entire wagon didn't catch fire.
Carloss Murray has been trying to rear the young Eagle caught on Saturday. After stopping tonight, he put it under a wagon...
...A while afterwards the men ran the wagon back and one of the wheels ran over its head and killed it dead.
a Sham trial Came of this evening before Judge Whipple the people the plantiff Col Markam defendant the Col was honerably aquited
Wrote in Heber's journal till half past 10 and then went to rest.
We have seen a number of romantic spots on our journey, but I consider our view this morning more sublime than any other.
a fine morning. the future prospect pleases & nothing to mar the pease that universally prevads.
This area has some of the most romantic sights: Chimney Rock, Scotts Bluff, the praire, the river. Pratt measured it: 792 yards across.
The route very good, hard and good travelling although a little crooked.
this morning is very pleasant and we start as usual
Good traveling, tolerable feed. Teams yet feeble though not failing at present.
12 miles by noon. Resting nearly opposite Scotts Bluffs. From "Ash Hollow" to "Chimney Rock" by our count 72 ? miles.
The appearance of Scots Bluff is so Artificial that the mind is scarcely willing to believe that the rude hand of nature had so formed it.
This day we passed the Scotch bluffs the Same appearance of decayed magnificance is to be Seen at that as well as maney outher places
Crossing the northernmost peak of Scotts Bluff. These bluffs look much like ancient ruins: high, steep, and broken.
It was a fine day, but now we are having a thunderstorm.
a heavey North wind, this evening, feed good, Road level.
The day was quite warm until near son set when it turned quite cool and rained a little we traviled 13 3/4
Camped just above the point where Scotts bluffs come the nearest to the river. Two antelopes killed. Raining quite fast.
Soil, road and grass good. Bottom still very wide. Bluffs are cut into all sorts of curious and fantastic forms by the elements.
Wind in the North and a shower of rain. We have plenty of fresh meat, chiefly Antilope. Have traveled today 13 3/4 miles.
traveled 14 miles today. killed 3 antelope to day. found some pigweed and picked a mess for greens. they relished well
Evening is cold and wet. Many are dancing again. I fear they dance too much, giving way to levity, and the camp may be scourged by the Lord.
Music and Dancing are a common recreation in camp tho we have to dispense with the Ladies, a very great desideration.
dark & lowerry, the bretherin called together & a vote to stay until a beter prospect in the weather
The morning cool, damp, cloudy and some rain. The brethren were called together and... all agreed to stay till it was fair.
Raining. We've decided to wait out the storm before moving on for the day.
Found several groups playing cards. Told my mind to those in Harmons wagon, my disapprovation in language not to be misunderstood.
Discussing the men's dancing, their mock trials &c and trying to reason with them to show that it will lead to serious results if they don't quit.
It was a Cold, cloudey disagreable day. We found tollerable plenty of drift wood which was verrey acceptable in a cold day.
Will warn them against profane language and persuad them to conduct themselves like men of God, or they would be sorry for it.
Storm has passed and bugle sounded to gather the teams. We'll head out for the day soon.
we've remained in camp until now on account of the rain
the weather is better and we are heading out
Er Kimball came to the next wagon where some of the boys were playing Cards. He told them his views & disapprobation...
The river takes a sharp turn from Scotts bluffs to the N.W. and almost north for a short distance. We laid by till about 11 fearing rain.
Sky overcast with clouds moderate rain during the forenoon so that we are just now starting out.
today we see a verrey fue trees on the South Side of the River which was a new Sight to us, for we had not seen aney timber for a long time
Damp...drisly...traveled 11 1/2 miles.
Traveled 11 1/2 mile followinig the course of the river which has been nearly North.
started and traveled 11/2 miles and camped for the night. made some poridge brown some coffee and went to bed early on account of the cold
Pres Young has been privately exorting some of the brethering to forsake an excess of mirthfulness & indulging in plays dances Sham trials
Retired early but was woken to go speak with Pres Young. We discussed the men's conduct and the need to stop it before it goes farther.
We are getting a boat at the fort to ferry across the river.
I spent the morning writing in Er Kimball's journal but felt very unwell having taken cold yesterday and been sick all night.
we have all been caled to gether to receve some instrution from Br Brigham.
The weather looking a little better, and the bugle sounded as a signal for the teams to be got together.
It's a rainy day so we wait until now to hitch up to start. The president calls the camp together from the center of the corral/
Brigham has called us together.
President Young has called us together for a conference.
Prest. began to lecture and teach upon the subject of fiddling & dancing, card playing, light mindedness, loud laughing and talking etc.
President Young... ordered each captain of ten to lead out their respective companies, and get all their men together.
a meating was called by President Young. he reproved the camp for their light and trifiling spirit that prevailed in there midst
The Prest. remarked against so much levity, card playing, dancing, etc., as it would lead to bad results
the day is to be spent in fasting and prayer and the twelve are to be in counsel by themselves
It was mistey and cold this morning and we did not start earley as usual.
Waited out more weather this morning. The bugle sounded, and we gathered the wagons. Pres Young is speaking, calling the camp to repentance.
Brigham said he would not go any further unless a covinent is made to do better. A vote was called and unanimosly carried.
pres Young says that he Should revolt at the idea of going any further with this Company while we have the Spirit which we now possess.
Brigham said it was no use to pursue our journey and further with the spirit that is in this camp at the present.
Pres Young is speaking against the excess of dancing & frollocking, playing cards, dice, domonoes, chequers
He also added that civil recreation is no harm if not carried to excess
Pres Young says Satan is working on our spirits. That if the men don't change, they'll be ruined, and he won't travel further.
More chastisement from Young abt the camp's quarrelsome spirit, the laziness of lounging in wagons instead of helping teams, etc.
thare is not a man present that does not feel the weight of his remarks, we are pioneers to the whole Church called to a responsible Station
Pres. Young admonishes us with much feeling and spirit because of growing evils in our midst which are leading the minds away from the Lord.
Pres Y finished. He expects more from Elders who have had the priesthood and temple ordinances. Tomorrow we fast and seek forgiveness.
br Kimball arose & aquiesed in all that Pres Young has said
Speaking. Reminding the men of the scourge that came with the camp that went to Missouri because of iniquity. Woodruff is next.
Br Woodruff says he owned the hand & kissed the rod & that he meant to reform.
he also advices that those that have cards, to burn them, dice & chequers like wise.
Bbrigham chastised us verry sharply for our wickedness and told us if we wood not repent of our folly he wood not go enny further with us.
all seemed willing to humble themselves and all with one acord convent to serv the Lord
He intends to go no further while the camp is under the influence of the spirit and he ascertains that all are present.
Among the gentiles the devil comes upon the us in the image of the mob. and we are out of reach of the gentiles so has to use other means
We are going like Abraham by faith knowing not whether we go to seek a home where the Lord has promised to locate a stake of Zion.
Colonel Markam just confessed that he had done wrong that he had indulged in all kinds of amusements.
Whereupon we all with one voice beginning with the twelve entered into a covenant to return unto the Lord with all our hearts.
Prest Young says that he is willing to forgive him & that he knew that Br Markam would do right
We are starting out after dedicating tomorrows sabbath to fasting, humiliation and prayer.
We now head out. this day makes me 27 years old on which I received quite a lesson, which I hope will result in much good & profit
For some time past the brethren many of them had given way to an eavel Spirit Such as dancing too mutch playing Cards, chequers, dice &c
and some would use foule language and neglected prayer and many things that was leading to eavel
President Young Seeing the situation improved an opertunity this morning to call the Camp togeather, he reproved them sharpley
after mutch good instruction and admonitions the Camp all covenanted to reform.
The remainder at the company at Pueblo are waiting to come with a detachment of the battalion that wintered there.
our Buffalo chips are of no account when it rains and but little when dry
yet I feel no inclination to complain for if ever a poeple was blest on earth it is us our prayers have verily been heard and answered
I feel a spirit of thankfulness all the time.
Set up camp after a very different day of travel--no quarreling, loud laughter, or swearing. Storm with thunder and lightening just passed.
after the meeting we started on our jerny and travled 8 milds and camped for the night
It it my turn to stand guard duty.
My guard duty is over, and the horn just blue for prairs. It is a dark and cloudy day.
The brethren have called a prair meeting.
I felt quite unwell through the night and also this morning, having severe pain in my bowels.
General meeting for prayers, confessions & exhortations.
we are fasting and praying this day. we will have a prayer meeting in the morning and preaching in the afternoon, the twelve will have a meeting by themselves.
Most of the brethren retired a little South of the Camp and had a prayer meeting, and as many as choose to, expressed their feelings.
Retiring a little south of camp for a prayer meeting where as many as who wish can express their feelings.
Gathering to take the sacrament. The Lord seems to accept the offerings of our hearts and has poured out his Spirit upon us.
Met again [a little south of the camp] to partake of the sacrement.
Returned to the same spot as the prayer meeting to partake of the sacrament with the camp.
15 of us are presenting ourselves before the Lord in a Prayer circle.
Our spirits are greatly refreshed by the manifestation of his Blessing upon us.
Going to a bluff with the 12 to put on priestly garments and pray, Young as voice. Those w/out garments will watch so we aren't interrupted.
A day for fasting and prayer. The twelve and nine others repaired to the hills, and clothed themselves after the manner of the Priesthood.
Black clouds threaten to rain on us as we pray; we'll stay, preferring to get wet than to lose the privilege.
The meeting is over, and a drizeling rain has started
I spent most of the PM in Er Kimball's wagon, with him, Prest. Young, Lorenzo and Phineas Young. Read minutes of yesterday's discourse.
we attended to the duties of the day and a good Spirit seamed to prevail a good maney expressed there determination to do better
Kimball, Benson & others walked to the bluffs. They invited me to go but I was so afflicted with Cramps in my bowels I could scarcely walk.
Sober day. Men remember their covenant to repent. Spent time in talks with Young, Lorenzo, and Phineas. Going off w/ Y and Benson to pray.
After another prayer suggested by Pres. Young we return to camp weary in body, satisfied with the proceedings of the day.
About 7 we had a fine view of a rainbow. Much joy and satisfaction, peace, quiet and harmony prevailing in the camp since our covenant.
I felt sick all day my mind was weighed down and it was a day I shall long remember
Prest. invited the Twelve and Bros. Snow, Shumway and Carrington to take a walk: We proceeded 2 ? miles to a peak.
We had a fine view of the bluffs from 20-30 miles apart, the rolling land along the river and the towering black hills.
Frost this morning but was a fine day.
Morning fine but cool. I feel quite unwell yet, and have been sick all night.
Clear and pleasant: I walked with the road pilots today. Turned off course to find grass.
cold morning, but there is peace & union in the camp.
Good sized cottonwood trees, old stumps and trunks accompanied by long fringes of willow and young cotton bushes.
After 12 1/2 miles we have encountered deep sand. The land is quite barren and the grass very thin.
Difficult day of travel on the teams. Poor feed. First timber we've seen since the 10th. We've used driftwood and buffalo chips since.
we found the land verrey Sandey and hard whelling. The fead was rather scarce. Today we came in sight of the Black hills
Camped in two parallel lines on the gravely bank of a swift run twenty to thirty feet wide and about one mile above its outlet.
Higbee killed a "long tailed deer" with a tail half a yard long. Eating it for supper, and it is very good.
The country looks perfectly barren, in some places nothing but a few weeks and "garlick." Some picked considerable of the latter to eat.
This deer which brother Higbee killed is of the "long tailed" species, having a tail more than half a yard long.
We have camped upon quite a large creek that came winding its way from the Bluffs. 558 miles] to Fort Larimie.
John Higby killed a fine deer. The feed is scarce owing to the poor yellow sandy soil
The month of May has passed over, and we have been permitted to proceed so far on our journey, being 531 miles from our families.
started early traveled 16/3 miles had a hard road. I was obliged to keep my bed the most of the day
after diner we started traviled till nearly sun down to find feed. we came to a creek and camped. I give it the name of gravily creek
All is still and quiet, the Camp well and in good spirits and a feeling of peace, union, and brotherly love seems to dwell in every breast.
Mr Young is quite unwell.
Er Kimball let me have his horse to ride.
Bro George A Smith starting to fulfill a prophecy by Pres Y that he'd be able to walk and carry a gun all day. He's starting out strong.
We are beginning to find a little timber chiefly a small growth of cottonwood. We have only had drift wood and buffalo chips for some time.
Clear and pleasant. Passed five old chimney stacks near the south bank. Grass scanty. Trees, small pine and cedar on both sides of the bluff
Trail is no longer nice and hard. It's soft and sandy, which is tough on the animals. Poor feed too.
Saw Fort Laramie about 4 miles to the South West.
Made camp in sight of Fort Laramie. 2 bros came from the fort who were with the Battalion. Others likely to come in the next fortnight.
Several men came down from the Fort about two miles from here, and made themselves known as part of the Mississippi company from Pueblo.
Camped in a semi-circle on the west river bank nearly opposite Fort St. John, 1 ? miles south on the Laramie Fork of the North Platte River.
we have traveled 12 miles and are now camped opposite Fort Larimie a little above the mouth of Larimie River.
2 Pueblo brethren visited us. They had been waiting for us at the Fort since the 16th of May. Distance 25 miles.
Indian babe "buried" nearby in a skin lashed to the boughs of a tree. Other dead laid across scaffolding. 2 of that sort across the river.
This was warm. The grass scarce. We reached Larramey . we traviled 12 1/2 miles and camped on the oppisit Side from the fort
We have learned that the families who wintered at Fort Pueblo, 250 south of this place, had been awaiting us there.
The brethren who came to report to us say that when they left Pueblo the other saints were expecting to start about the first of June.
We have traveled from Winter Quarters to Fort Laramie 543 1/4 miles, and we have travelled it in 7 weeks lacking half a day.
We have traveled 540 miles from Winter quarters. I have 2,800 miles sense the 16 of last July 1846 to this date June first 1847.
we traveled 12 miles and found ourselves at Fort Larermee. we camped for the night. the scene is romantic.
opisite to us stands the ruins of the old Fort and front of us is a large Black walnut tree which I assure you is a rarity.
a little to the left of us is a tree that has the bones of an Indian child done up very snug in skins
Started over the river in company with the Twelve and others to view the Fort and also learn something in regard to our journey &c.
Went up to the remains of an old Fort, called "Fort Platte" which is near the banks of the river; the outside walls still standing.
Crossed the river with others to see the remains of Fort Platte. Insides are burnt ruins. Walls are "Daubies," Spanish brick with no mortar.
Proceeded to "Fort Laramie." We were politely welcomed by Mr Bordeaux who appears to be the principal officer.
Three portable blacksmith shops are in operation shoeing horses and repairing wagons.
2 miles farther, now at Fort Laramie, rebuilt with Daubies. Greeted by Mr. Bordeau, who gave insight on the best trails and places to avoid.
[At Ft. Laramie] a pair of Moccassins worth a dollar, a Lariette a dollar, a pound of tobacco $1.50 and a gallon of whiskey $32.
we are now camped on the bank of the Platte and shall lay by three or four days to wash and do some blacksmithing
Visiting the fort's trade--they trade mostly with the Sioux. Flour 25 cents/lb, sugar & coffee $1, tobacco dollar and a half.
This spring they shipped 600 bales of robes (10 in bl.) 400 miles overland to Fort Pierre on the Missouri, and loaded on steerage boat
Taking a stop at the fort's blacksmith shop at the southwestern entrance. They have very little iron. South of the fort is mostly stables.
We have secured the use of a very good Flat Boat owned by the Fur company for our company for the sum of fifteen dollars.
Beaudeux  revealed that it is 300 miles to Fort Bridger in Black's Fort of Green River, where the Oregon and California Forks.
We spent the day in making araingemants for Crossing the river as we could not pas the Black hills on this Side.
Got on board the Boat and had a pleasant ride about 3 miles down the Laramie Fork to its mouth, the current being swift.
The traiders had a flat boat at this place and we chartered it to take our teams over for fifteen dollars. The traiders was verrey friendly.
It is Said they never have any sicknes in this place. The atmosphear is verrey pure. We can see the high hills Said to be fiftey miles off
we spent the day in washing and in fixing up things. the Brethren hired a fery boat of the traders and fixed a place to ferry
Higbee and others went fishing for dinner at the fork. Just returned with 60 or 70 not very large ones, which will be split among the camp.
The twelve and others crossed the north fork to the ruins of Fort Platt. Proceeded 2 mi. to Fort St. John. Mr. Beaudeux received us civily.
Chartered the companies flat boat, and took a fine ride down the rapid current of Laramie to its mouth, about ? mile below our camp.
Renting Mr. B's boat to ferry our wagons across the river for $15. He'd do it himself for 25 cents a wagon, but that would mean $18.
we got up early and are commencing to ferry accross the River.
The wind Come, this morning quite colde from the east.
The 3rd and 1st division have commenced ferrying
Brother Amasa M Lyman and three others left earlier for Pueblo to meet the company and bring them along.
Today Elder Amasa Lyman has started with three others on horseback with dispatches to Pueblo.
Lyman and 3 others heading for Pueblo. Young, myself and others going with them a pace to send them off with a council and then prayer.
We are busily engaged in crossing the river.
Returned from sending off the brethren. A storm has hit: hail and lightning. Ferrying wagons over the river must stop til the storm passes.
Lone horsemen just arrived at the Fort to report 5,000 emigrants and 2000 waggon on the road who will probably to arrive here tomorrow.
The foort stands in the forks betwean the Laramey fork and the Platt. The Platt is about 20 rods wide and the fort about half as large
A heavey storm of wind and rain has caused a cessation in our ferrying
Ferrying ceased on account of a hard storm of rain and hail accompanied by sharp lightning and heavy thunder. Beginning again soon.
Storm abated enough to get most wagons over, but started up again with heavy rain. Three companies will have to wait to cross til morning.
All but 17 waggons are across the river, and camped on the opposite shore.
it commenced raining about 1 and rained until 3 when they commenced ferrying again. the teams did not all get over this day
We have nearly completed ferrying our teams across the river.
The bretherin have finished ferrying.
The last wagon just ferried successfully across the river.
All wagons ferried over. Mr. Beaudeux, said ours was the most civil Company. Left letters for Father and my wife.
We leave Fort John, Brother Crow is joining our group.
At the fort to settle for the boat. Learned best area to go: Bear River Valley has good feed, water, timber, little snow, abundance of trout
Maney of the bluffs are composed of a substance about as hard as unbaked brick, and the stormes have worne them in curious shapes
Started on the Oregon Road. The company from Pueblo joined our line
Bro Crows company arrived half an hour ago. Will be part of the 2nd division. Heading out now on our travels again.
Almost 8 miles from Laramie now. We've hit a steep slope and must lock the wagon wheels to get down it. Hope we'll get down safe.
We finished crossing and I went out to the front. It is made raw brick about the houses are attached to the wall on the in side
Reached the Black Hills. We can look down on steep hills the worst since we left Winter Quarters--the most circumscribed view we ever had.
Newcomers-5 wagons, 9 men, 5 women and 3 children—organized into a company. We now have 79 wagons, 96 horses, much livestock. 8 ? miles.
There is about 40 men belonging to this post but the most of them are out a trading &c
At this point we strike the Organ trail a Compeny of emegrants for that place are expected in today.
The slope detained us some, but we all got down safe. Went 1/2 mile farther, and now we're setting up camp. Storm with thunder is coming.
At the foort they ask 25 cts per lb for Flor & dollar for coffe, 1.0 for suger, They ask the same for buffelo robes that they do in St Louis
After passing some low sand ridges we ascended a steep hill onto a low bottom 8 miles from the fort where we found good feed and camped.
Mr Young went and visited the Traders at the fort. I baked some bread and pies and fried some cakes. started at 12 traveled 8 miles.
Guard duty again
Have to talk with George S. Billing about the way he treats his team and counsel him to be more gentle with them &c.
Nearly all the teams ready pull out when it was discovered that several oxen are missing. Must find them before we can resume our journey.
pleasant morning. We kept along the river about 10 miles from the foort, then left it, and crost the hills, some of them was tollarble Steep
We are compelled to leave the river and taking a circuitous route and a rough and hilly road.
Started late and halted. The road lay across a bad point of rock. We then kept by the dry bottom of a warm, spring run.
Sandstone bluffs. Considerable bunch grass. Rested. Soon ascended a steep and long rock hill. Passed an emigrant Company of 9 wagons.
Traveling over uneven, rocky bluffs. Brother Crow's cart just turned over. It's not hurt, but we must upright it before going on.
Our trail has intersected the main Origon road.
More broken and rough surfaces, steep slopes, rocky and gravelly trails. Jars the wagons something terrible.
Crossed Bitter Creek. Camped on its west bank. Traveled 10 ? miles. Grass good. I guarded cattle. Rained considerably through the night.
Today's camp site has good feed and water. Elder Clayton has taken to putting up sign boards every 10 miles. He put up 2 today.
We struck the dry bed of cottonwood creek and followed it up till we found wood, water and good feed.
We have found a small party of emigrants; 11 waggons only bound for St. Marys river. We are halted for Sunday, having traveled 17 miles.
We had a little shower this afternoon and quite a shower in the night. We camped on a fine little Creek Called Cottonwood
traveled 17 miles. one of our oxen appears to be sick. toward night we will take him out, and hope he will soon got better.
Warm, but appearance of rain. The order of the day is that we all fast until after meetings. All is peace and union
Assembling for meeting and prayer. Today is to be a sabbath day of fasting.
We have had an interesting and Proffitable meeting.
We held meeting. the Camp we had passed went past us & anouther Camp of 21 waggons passed us all ox teams and 3 to 5 yoak to the waggeon.
4 from a Missouri company that passed this morning coming over. Looks like they're scared of us, being as some persecuted the Mormons.
Missourians' guide says there's water in 6 mi but not again for 15 after that. We'll move on to be sure can reach the next water tomorrow.
Day of fasting and prayer. Rain. 2 Emigrant Co. passed--the larger is mostly from Illinois and Mississippi with 20 wagons and 2 carriages.
a band of emegrants, 19 waggons and 2 cariages, just passed us.
Moved to shorten the distance to the next water. Passed the larger Emigrant Company Camp.
Wagons halting while I go with Young and Woodruff to look for a camp site. Gentiles are camped nearby. I think we'll find good feed.
Upon the council of the emegrant party we have chosen to move up 5 miles so as to better cross a route with no water tomorrow.
19 wagons of more Oregon emmigrants are coming with us.
Drove our 3rd  ten mile stake before camping. Smaller co. camped just ahead of us. Brother Frost is blacksmith for both co.s of Emigrants.
Grass good. We’re told that we are now as near Laramie Mountains as we will be.
Have set up camp at a good site. Burr Frost setting up his anvil to do some little jobs like fixing a carriage spring for the Gentiles.
Brother Frost is doing some black smitthing for the emegrants. We are now 80 miles from Fort John
camping for the night in the most beautiful place we have found since we started. I churned and picked a mess of greens, ate supper and going to bed
The larger Immigrant Company us passed us and turned off Cottonwood Creek. Thirteen wagons from Andrew City, Mo. came up to us. Wind E.S.E.
Dr R left a letter in a guide board giving a history of our journey thus far for the benefit of the next company of Saints when they arrive.
It is a fine clear morning. The emegrants have started before us
about when we were baiting anouther Camp of Moovers for Oregan 13 waggens in number passed us
We are gradually ascending through a hollow bottom following the course of a dry creek.
Noon halt. We have a fine view of Laramie little mountains caped with snow or quartz.  Road good except the gravel bed. Latitude 41°21'51".
Stopped for dinner. We can see the snow on Laramie peak; about 18 miles distance
13 waggons more of Oregon emegrants passed us while we took refreshment here.
Standing at the top of a bluff. Can see the Black Hills, apparently so named due to the deep green pines that look nearly black from here.
Coming down the bluff has been difficult; lots of big cobble stones. Men are removing them to make the trail easier for those coming behind.
After 9 1/2 miles we are now opposite the Principle Peak of the Black Hills which appeared to be still partly covered with snow.
We have passed over some tollarble hevey hills, The grass was good and Considerable timber. We have had Some showers to day.
traveled over a mountanious country. a camp from Mo Missouri came up with us but seemed in a hurry to get away from us
We are now about oppiset the Larame Pieque of the Black hills. They are high and Snow is in plain view on the top of it.
Rolled over 2 ridges. View of an extensive, very broken, barren country. Stuck 4th 10-mile stake. Camped on the bank of Horse Shoe Creek.
I kill the first black-tail deer I've ever seen.and the Oregon emigrants begin to pass.
Stopped for the day. I discovered a spring 8' across and 2' deep. Since I found it, I'm naming it after myself.
Br Crow tried yoking wild steers; needed several men w/ lariats to help. Ropes wound around his legs and the nigh ox. Had to cut him loose.
We meet some traders who have crossed the north fork in a rawhide boat which they left.
We set out to find the boat but could not find it. We kill a lot of meat and the river is full and rapid.
After ascendng 3 1/2 miles we have found a fine camp.
We met several companies of emmigrants. They pay us provisions which we will use gratefully.
Br Crow's hunter felled a deer; isn't willing to share it according to camp rules--he's not a church member. We agreed to pay him in goods.
We found some good grass, 1/2 leg high. Best we've seen since we started. Found a beautiful spring that is now called Heber's Spring.
We made 13 miles today. Had a smart shower come up. 4 antilope killed.
Seen several buffalos. Turned from the creek, ascending the hills. Some hills pretty hard to pull up, and had to double some teams.
The way is steep. We are obliged to double team. The road is very stony, and 15 men are imployed throwing stone out of the road.
Climbing up more bluffs. These are the most difficult we've ever had--several very steep spots where we have to double teams.
I see a buffalo about 1/2 mile off! That's the first we've seen since about May 21.
I've the ill luck of having broke a wagon wheel upon the road which has been nothing more than up and down, though smooth.
Stopping for drink, Harriet Crow sat on the tongue of her wagon. The cattle started and threw her under the wheel. Her foot might be broken.
A sister is washing Harriet's foot with camphor. She's in a lot of pain. While there's much bruising, her foot doesn't appear to be broken.
Bro Frost welded and set the wagon wheel during our noon halt without detaining the camp.
A wagon wheel rolled over the leg of a woman in Crow's ten. Put up the fifth ten miles stake. Crossed the river LaBonte or Big Timber Creek.
Another bluff to cross, this one rocky and uneven. There is much wind, making it cold. Harriet Crow seems to be in less pain.
We had maney hevey hills to cross [today] which ware mostley rockkey and graaviley. The day was colde, wind west.
We just reached La Bonte river. We will ford it and camp on the other side.
5 traders and trappers rode in. Albert Carrington with several others worked on the road all day throwing away pebbles, etc. 8 3/4 miles
traveled over a rough rugged road. a company of Traders visited us, gave us some intelegence respecting the road
Some traders from fort Bridger stopped by. There were some letter sent by them.
After 15 1/2 miles we are now camped at Big Timber creek. A company of traders from Fort Bridger are is camped near us.
Stopping at a traders camp, which has tolerable feed. Several men sending letters back with traders headed east.
Traders say they have a ferry of sorts made of skins to cross the next river and will let us use it if Bro Crow goes ahead of the Gentiles.
Rolled on at 5 a.m. to find better grass. Stopped by a traders camp.  Started again soon.
20 of our best teams and some horsemen have  left us in advance of us crossing of the Platt to make some preparations for crossing.
I wrote a letter to Elmeda but did not finish it in time to send it
More rocky, uneven terrain. Have to get across a gully with steep sides. It'll take help getting most wagons up the other side.
fine day. after going about 3 miles we crost Red bank creek, steep banks not verrey high; fine streem. some timber.
We just came to a valley that is picteresqe. The soil is a dark red, but nearer the summit it is white.
Lots of red dirt. Odd on the eyes. Spotted a 3" toad with horns that runs like a lizard. Has a hard shell and hard pricks on each side.
The mountaineers also report that the detachment at Fort Pueblo will soon be on our track.
15 wagons sent on to the fort crossing. The roads are very good for a hilly country. No very bad hills. Flag found. 11 ? miles.
5 mountaineers have overtaken us and report that the Mormon Battallion crossed the Mountains and went on to California last winter.
Camped on the bank of the river La Prele in sight of an Emigrant Co. A few traders passed west. Grave headstone marked J. Hembree, 1843
Made encampment. The wild sage smells very strong of Turpentine and Camphor. Mint is in abundance too and has a strong smell by the stream.
We reached Alapier creek a distance of 19 miles and have made camp.
traveled 19 miles. we sent a company on ahead to fix for ferrying across the Platt River
Some cloudy otherwise very pleasant there being a light fine breeze from the W.S.W. Crossed two wet and two dry runs.
More rough roads, steep bluffs, and crooked roads today.
I have been agreeably disappointed in the country of the Black hills, instead of continual barrenness we have found it beautiful.
Crossed 3 cricks today, and are at the banks of the 4th. Stopping for Dinner.
Nooning on the backs of the Fourche Boisee, a fine stream. Grass tolerable. Cottonwood trees and willows in abundance. 8 ? miles.
We have struck the Platte.
Came to the North Fork of the Platte making 90 1/2 miles from fort laramie.
The road is far more even now, but it's also sandy, which is hard on the animals, and there's no good feed.
Crossed Deer Creek. Plenty of herring, succers & catfish. 9th 10-mile stake put up. A coal bed was discovered, first we found on the Platte.
Found a sick horse, likely left by a company ahead. Col. Markham bled it in the mouth. Found there's nothing could do and left it.
Fine day, rather more hilley. Crossed a number of streams. We went 17 3/4 miles and campt on a buitiful streem with considerable large timber
Quite a quantity of fish were caught with a hook in the crick. I caught 6 of about a 1/2 lb each. Grass is good. Exelant camping place.
We traveled today 18 miles and are camped tonight on Deer Creek. This is the most delightfull place we have seen since we left the states.
Many fishing at the river. Elr Carrington found a coal mine nearby. This would be a good place to settle--good land, feed, water, coal.
A large creek of clear water stony bottom and the way our boys are hauling out the fish is not slow.
one of our Miners has discovered an extensive bed of excellent Bituminous coal up the creek and a quary of equally excellent sand stone.
traveled 19 miles and camped near a beautiful stream. the scenery is ramantic.
the grass is up a 9 or 10 inches high and yet within six miles there is beds of snow to be seen
It is my turn to stand guard.
We have overtaken a party of emigrants who are preparing to cross the river.
Examined the Coal bed. 8 to 10 ft. thick. We traced it for about a mile then stoped for want of time. Excellent quality. Very extensive.
This would be a good location for a small settlement. Soil lime and clay. Cottonwoods plenty and good. Coal in abundance for generations.
The rivulets are lush with water from the melting snow which whiten the north sides of the Peaks of a high range of hills on our left.
Distance9 ? miles. Saw several rattlesnakes. Tenth ten mile stake put up this forenoon. Latitute 12°51'47". Crossed two small clay runs.
Stopped at a grove with plenty of feed and timber. Bro Hancock killed an antelope but could carry only half of it and left the rest behind.
Crossing a crooked, muddy creek. Descent and ascent both difficult on account of having to turn short in the middle.
Distance 7 ? miles. 11th 10-mile stake put up. Evening very mild and pleasant. Eight lopes killed.
Pres Young and I are ahead and see a camp of gentiles 1/2 mile away. We'll stop here for the night. It's too far to the next water.
fine weather and mostley good roads we killed plenty of Antilope and some Deer. This day we traviled 17 miles and camped on the river bank.
We have traveld 17 miles today up the Platte.
There is a range of black hills paralel to the river, partially covered in snow. One of the emegrants brought a snow ball to camp from there
Men from the gentile camp came to visit. One went up the nearby mountains and returned w/ snow wrapped in a shirt. Gave us a snowball.
Gentiles report having killed 3 bears and a buffalo between here & the mtn. We've killed 8 antelope today all in all.
traveled 14 miles and camped near the Platt River where we overtook a company from Mo crossing the river
we had to deminish our allowance of Bread and eat more meat which came verrey hard on me for fresh meat alwayes gave me the bowel complaint.
Our camp have killed 7 antilope today
Col. Markham learned that O. Jennings was principle agent in killing Wm. Bowman, one of the guard who let Joseph & others free in Missouri.
Apparently from some cause, the mob suspected Bowman had helped Joseph & other so they rode him on a bar of iron till they killed him.
My helth has been verrey poor today. we had tollarble good road
Trying to find a place to cross the river. Too deep to ford, too swift for a ferry. The gentiles tried that--rolled over and broke bows &tc.
reached the main foord The watter was so high that we could not foord it. The bluffs were nearley covered with pine, it looked like bushes
the brethren are confabulating about whether to cross teh river here or to go about 4 miles ahead where there might be a ferry
Reached our advance party who had done a good business with the passing Emigrant Co., smithing, wagon fixing, and trading.
They received for aiding with their crossing flour, two dollars and fifty cents a hundred, and for trade and work, bacon and cash.
One of the Emigrant companies named Childs would have been drowned had he not been picked up by some of our men in our leather boats.
Heading out again. Decided to go farther for a better place to cross. We think we found a suitable place.
After twelve miles we came to where our advance party were engaged in ferrying over a party of Oregon Emigrants for $30 in provisions.
Brother Chesley ferried some oregon emegranst and recieved about 33 dollars in renumeration.
Brothers Rappleye & Johnson are takeing different directions to visit the Mountains south of us.
More coal, an inexhaustable supply of fuel for Whitney's railroad or any other project. Very handy to the whole tide of emigration.
Encampment set up near some brethren who went before. They ferried some gentiles across for a fee and traded goods and services.
Objects in this countrey appear cloas at hand when they are at a grate distance.
New supplies are a blessing; many were low on breadstuffs. We have lots of flour, bacon, and crakers. Also a horse. Blacksmith made $6.
started at 8 traveled 7/2 miles and stopped to bate our teams then came on 4 miles and camped. it being the place to cross the Platt River
Brothers Rappleye & Johnson have not returned. A file of horsemen with the Bugler have started out search of them.
Our hunters have killed 3 buffalo which was very fat, a black bair, 2 or 3 cubs & several antilope
Artemus Johnson & Tunis Rappleyee missing. The former started out hunting this morning, the latter went to get some snow after we arrived.
The search party has returned, but found the bretheren not.
The bretheren have blundered into camp with half of a young Elk packed from the Mountains.
Their extreme Mortification of being the cause of so much anxiety served greatly to lighten the merited chastisement from the President.
Rappleyee back, led by the fires and bugle calls. Johnson found on the mountain. It looks 2 mi away, but all agree it is more like 8 or 10.
They reported the mountains to be full of Bear, Elk, Antilope and sheep and snow from 6 to 10 feet deep in Places.
Some snow brought from the mountains and exhibited in the camp
Very pleasant morning. We have been called to meeting, and Bishop Rownday is speaking.
Little cloudy, but still and warm. Horn blowing for meeting.
The Oregon emigrants are continually splitting up their companies and should do away with their selfishness and become one
He urges obeying counsel. Brother Joseph once told him to drive horses between two trees where not one could fit. and he said he could not
Brother Jospeh stared at him. Drive through. He jerked the reins and popped his whip.
There says Jospeh, I only want you to try. That will do.
He wishes the saints understood they should not try to change the laws of heaven. It does not give us liberty to dethrone Jehovah.
This is the liberty of the gosple. Not giving men licents to commit sin but delivering them from the bondage of sin.
The Gosple liberates men from bondage and here is liberty. It takes adverse conditions and reverses them.
Speaking at prayer mtg, telling the men to avoid everything which would divide and disunite us.
We are holding a meeting and Brother Kimball is speaking about the alienating principle of men to feel independent
having meeting
Teaching of the potter. The Lord designs to exalt us if we're passive in His hands & don't mar the process to be thrown back on the wheel.
Young: Gospel gives liberty to do all that will benefit & exhalt, but not to infringe on others' rights or transgress the law of God.
Prest Young finished a discourse on the subject of obeying council.
We had meeting as usual Bro Brigham Young, Heber Kimbel & Orson Pratt gave mutch good instruction
