Good teaching by Elders Kimball, Young and Pratt. After meeting operations, set afoot for crossing.
Prayer meeting dismissed and now preparing dinner. Soon 1st division will be sent w/ wagons to the mtn to find poles to build a raft.
Provision was divided among the Camp. Truley the hand of the Lord was in it and he has blessed us all the way thus far
Passed off as usual with a meeting in camp and as a day of rest to ourselves and teams.
2nd division crossed river and built a raft. 1st division didn't return from gathering poles until after dark. They report much good timber.
Ferrying the first division's empty wagons over for an hour now. Slow work due to the swift current.
We begin crossing the Platte today. The wind is blowing very strong and the current is rapid.
We're ferrying waggons across the river today.
we are commencing to ferry across the River. they have a tedious job, the water is high and the current strong.
Trying an experiment: 2 empty wagons lashed together, drawing them across with ropes across the river.
We have managed to swim our horses and cattle and cross our loads in the skiff. We are attempting to float the wagons across.
We made rafts of Pine & Fir rails [that] we got from the mountains or bluffs on which we crossed the wagon
Water rolled one wagon atop the other. Bent bows considerable. Lost $20 of goods (iron &tc) Pack neglected to take out. Trying again w/ 4.
Began to cross at 4:45 a.m. I’m working hard unloading wagons to the boat, and then loading up on this side.
Got them safely over, but one wagon still rolled, and many bows are bent. Going to try one more time with a single wagon.
Several waggons were severely damaged while ferrying. The currant is too strong. They capsized in the middle of the stream
Current is too swift for this method. We'll end up with too many repairs. Resorting to the slow but safer way: ferrying the wagons across.
Two wagons locked together by means of poles placed under them shared the same fate. This plan has been abandoned as it is too dangerous.
Lashed 4 waggons together with poles and then hauled them through the water by means of a rope.
Even with a rope attached throught he tongue, the current rolls the wagons as though they are nothing but a log.
We lose a few waggons and bows. We leave a ferry until the families who are following Should come up on.
From 3 to 4: The worst storm we have had. First wagons were loaded safe before the storm for which we felt to thank the Lord.
We had a thunder shower with hevey winds that broak us off
We get everything across the river Safe, except we drown one horse belonging to Brother Crow.
We just got my waggon across. We had to build rafts to get the waggons across. I have worked in the water nearly all day.
Men are tired & wet, having spent the day in the water carrying goods across. Water is rising; at times it's been up to their armpits.
Captain Fowler's and Grover's ten crossed about 9 and finished crossing our wagons at a little past two on a raft all dry and safe.
Brother Adams crossed 7 and Grover 4.  13 other wagons pulled over by ropes badly wet and some rolled over and damaged and bows broken.
Another day of ferrying.
Our next plan is to try small rafts to get the wagons across.
Back to rafting more wagons across. Slow going with heavy winds. Making two more rafts to help speed the process.
we are still crossing the River. the wind is against us and do not make much head way
More wagons to get across the river. Swimming some stock over today.
The difficulty of pulling a raft in so deep and swift water sweeps them down river one to two miles before it makes the other shore.
We crossed what we could but the watter was quite high and rizing The River at this place is about 1/2 of a mile wide and runs fast
Bro Crow sent his animals to swim across, but they neglected to take off the lariat from the horses. Buffalo horse appears to be drowning.
Some men went to the horse's relief on the cutter, freed it, and succeed in dragging it to shore. It is perfectly dead.
Compnies of emegrants was coming and one comp Had allready ariven and they had no means for crossing and wanted us to cross them over
So partley for accommodation and partley for the pay we concludes to have a Small Comp stop for a length of time to make a sort of ferrey
Quite a number of loads and wagons got over all safe. One of R. Crow’s Indian ponies got tangled in a rope and drowned.
We decided to leave some men behind to wait for more brethren and help them ferry across. They'll earn money by ferrying gentile companies.
We built a larger raft, and that seemed to help. An Oregon company of 18 waggons commanded by Capt Smith came, & employed us to ferry them.
Word came that a large company is near. If this be true they're doubtless brethren. We have hopes they'll overtake us before we get through.
Some back abt 3 mi to make 2 canoes and build a good raft or a ferry on them. Others upriver digging & making puncheons to lay on the raft.
Several men left to begin roughing out 2-3 canoes for a new canoe-boat ferry. Busy day crossing emmigrants.
a Comp. was sent to git the timbers which was a number of miles off and the remainder continued crossing over as before.
Still more ferrying. Some of the men have been dispatched to make some canoes for a ferry boat about 4 miles down the river
A set of hands has been set to build two canoes, 2 1/2 feed wide and 23 feet long to assist in the ferrying.
With Craig & Woodsworth managing a raft, Craig fell overboard. Had to swim back to shore. Woodsworth alone on the raft fighting the wind, drifting downstream.
Wordsworth drifted near 2 miles past the landing place before assistance could be got to him in the cutter.
Our next attempt is two rafts constructed with oars well maned.
commenced making a raft to carry waggons with a part of their loading
This attempt is the best we have tried. The two rafts can effect a landing in about half a mile. The rafts are then towed up with oxen.
Ferried long and hard all day against wind. Hard to count the wagons across, as they're spread across a mile. Many still on the other side.
Another company of waggons came up, and we engaged to ferry them for $1.50 per waggon. The men are nearly done with the canoos.
21 emigrant wagons, mostly from Illinois, crossed 4 or 5 miles below us. They’ve buried their first 2, within 150 miles of this place.
These are the first deaths to our knowledge in any of the Emigration Companies. The canoe company returned with 2 good logs, 23 feet long.
the Comp. returned with timbers for two canoes. The wind continued to blow down the river which made it handy crossing.
Ferrying began early. 2 companies of Missourians arrived and are making application to be ferried over at a dollar and a half a wagon.
President Young’s wagon crossed. The boys are busy at the two canoes to float the canoe-boat.
2nd company has 10 wagons. Offering to pay each man on the raft (10) 50 cents each man extra, if they would set their company over first.
Rockwood contracted w/ the 1st company. But it's Markham's raft day--he made no contract. He'll take the hint & accept the 2nd offer.
We finally have all our waggons acrost the river. A company of 9 men are staying here until the rest of our brethren come up.
All our wagons are over but mine and Pres. Young's. After we get over safely, we'll begin ferrying the Missourians.
We finished crossing and then commenced crossing the outher Comp. while a Set of hands was working on the new boat.
We finished crossing our loads. Wind strictly from the west by south. Water high. The canoes are ready for planking.
The wind shifted and blew a stiff cold breeze from the north by east.
We have been employed crossing other small companies with our rafts and skiffs for the price 150 and 200 for waggon.
got our waggons across the river and fitted them up
Some of the brethren are still working at ferrying.
Made camp late tonight--several brethren still ferrying the Missourians and likely will until daylight.
This morning everey thing was covered with frost
Still ferrying gentiles. Won't move on today; we must finish the raft and be sure to be paid for the ferrying.
We passed one Emigration Company of ten wagons and most all of another with eighteen or nineteen wagons.
Using the canoes, coupled with cross timbers, and covered with puncheon, and manned with good oars we can cross a waggon with its load
our Brethren are buisied in ferrying the Mo Companies. they took about70 dollars in provisions and nessaries which was a help to the camp
Launched our canoes. They made much quicker and better trips than our rafts.
Just finished helping some emegrants to ferry acrost the river. The ferry works well.
It is providence of God in getting the supplies which we needed in exchange for crossing more emegrants.
I have been selected to stay here and run the ferry.
We spent the day crossing the emegrants
We have finished our crossing of the Platte.
The 12 meeting separate from the camp. 10 brethren will tarry behind at the ferry.
Young counseling Elders: They grasp at things ahead of them & which belong to others instead of seeking after & bringing up those behind.
Council meeting adjourned. Returned to my wagon to find 65 very nice fish Clayton caught and brought me--each about 1/2 pound.
9  men left under Bro. Grover to ferry emigrant wagons. Eric Gliners stopped, with our counsel, making 10.
We leave the river. Brother Woodruff and I went ahead to the rock (Independence).
Starting on our journey again. Teams in good order--many remark that the stock has fatted so much here that they scarcely know them.
Thomas Grover with eight other men and a blacksmith will stay to continue ferrying emigrants until the arrival of our other companies.
We left a Comp. to attend the ferrey and started on. We left the river and found a hilley countrey tho not bad
Started onto a good road. Noon halt within ? mile of a large spring. Distance, 11 ? miles. Within sight of the high red banks of the Platte
Stopping at good grass after a difficult day of travel over rough terrain and odd soil that is white with black and white.
Decided to harness the teams and move on to the spring 1/2 mi away--first water since the ferry over 11 miles back.
Ended up going past the spring to the lake, where there is good grass as well as water. Will resume our journey shortly.
It is barren country with little feed.
Rolled over a good road with the usual scenery. Traveled 10 1/2 miles and camped near a small spring.
Brackish water on the other side. Grass scanty. Fuel sage and other brushes with a little buffalo chips.
We traveled today 21 1/2 miles and are obliged to camp in a misserable mirey hole of salt springs and marshes with scarce feed and fuel.
Camping at a miserable place: water the animals won't even drink, swampy mud an ox can sink into, no fuel. But many buffalo.
We stay all night with a company of emigrants. The camp fears some evil has become us.
we went 21 1/2 miles and Camped in a place without mutch grass, and all the wood we could git was the ded wilde Sage
Alarm sounding that an ox is mired in mud. Truly, this is a gloomy, cheerless, filthy place. To be avoided in the future for campgrounds.
traveled 20 miles had hard traveling. camping near the poison spring. three of the cattle got into the mire but suffered no material injury
Cannon fired for them at midnight.
This a poor place of rest for the Sabbath. We will start out for a better camp.
Proceeding on. 2 more oxen were found almost buried in mud. Seems a universal feeling to leave this place as early as possible.
We go to Independence Rock at the highest peak and offer prayer.
While at our devotions the emigrants bury a woman by the rock in the east. She died this morning. Her name was Rachel Morgan
She was the third one of the family to have died. It is thought that the sickness was occasioned by cooking their victuals in new brass ware
She leaves behind three small children.
For want of gras for our teems we went on, we found some small patches of gras and some water in several places.
traveling on account of feed
Started at 5:15  to find better grass. Made 3 ?  difficult miles and stopped by a spring run with some grass and got breakfast.
Have reached two very deep ravines to cross which requires some care in teamsters to prevent accident.
We came to Willow Springs which is a good Camp ground for a small Comp. We rose a high hill and we could See banks of Snow on the mountains
The camp comes up and are glad to see us.
We are passing the noted willow spring.
Passed Willow Spring. Looks like an oasis in this barren country. Came in view of the left ridge of the Sweet Water and its ragged spurs.
We meet a company from Oregon at Pacific Spring and Major Harris an old mountaineering man from whom we learn a great deal about the country
We get some papers and one number of the California Star published by Samuel Branon.
He had gone to California by way of water with a company of saints.
Halting to feed in a ravine. Plenty of grass for teams, good stream of water. Have travelled 9 mi over sandy, barren land.
While we're halted, we decided to vote for President Young to take the lead with his wagon and try to proceed a little faster.
Some teams very tired. I walked the whole 20 miles today. W. Woodruff and John Brown went ahead to scout for camps.
We made camp half a mile off the main road on a beautifull creek which empties into Sweetwater having traveled 20 1/2 miles.
Mountain Sage covers this barren country. In fertile spots it grows rank and becomes quite a shrub. It is our only fuel tonight.
Many alkali lakes w/ a nauseus smell. Saleratus here said to raise bread equal to the best in the east. Lorenzo Young gathered a pail.
The water we're passing is NOT the Sweetwater. Travelers say it's poisoned More likely it's animals drink too much from the salt.
We passed a number of salt ponds as the salt Covers the ground where the water is dried away. a bushel could be geathered in a fue hours
It has a differant taste from Common salt. It tasts as if mixed with hemlock and it will ancer in sted of salerates to rais bread with
Wilford Woodruff and J. Brown still out. Noon halt on the left bank of the Sweet Water, 1/4 mile from the road side on Rock Independence.
7? miles travel has brot us to Sweetwater near the celebrated Independence Rock.
Arrived at the Sweetwater at 12. Rode ahead to find a place to halt. We found a suitable place a little South West of the Rock Independence.
When the wagons came in sight, we waved our hats but they didn't see the sign and stopped 2 miles south of us. Have to go get them.
We are fording the beautiful river a mile above the Rock. The water runs into our lowest waggon beds but appeared to be rapidly falling.
We reached Sweatt water at Independance Rock. we crossed the creek which was about three rods wide and 2 1/2 ft deep.
At Rock Island a board read, 'To Fort John, 175 ? miles.' Crossed the Sweet Water, 2 ? feet deep. Passed through 'Devil Gate'.
It is a singular place and a fine Situation for miles. This is called the devels gate.
Below camp the Sweet Water rushes through a granite spur, falling 10-15 feet. Both walls rise vertical, the right to the hight of 400 feet.
Having traveled 15 miles today, we are camped about a mile above what is commonly called the Devils Gate.
I followed a foot path till I was under the highest point of rocks. The river roars, compelling me to retreat by the way I entered.
Harriet Young made bread with the saleratus--nice and light, & no unpleasant taste. Says the saleratus is twice as strong as that in stores.
traveled 19 miles and camped in a beautiful place. had good feed
Our roads laying off from the river, chiefly has been sandy and rough, no particular change in the products or face of the country.
A young man named Columbus Austin of Morson Co., Ill, of the Emigrant Co. drowned on the 18th by swimming a horse across the north Fork.
The weather was verrey warm and plenty of Snow in plain Sight on the high hills--or what is Called Sweet water mountains.
Passed a pond on our left and began to wind among hills. The prairie bottom
After a 2-hour break, we're on our way again, passing another lake with banks mostly of white saleratus.
Crossing a steep creek, Driggs' horses sprang forward & broke the harness to pieces. Oxen hauled wagon to not hinder others from crossing.
we have traveled thro the most barren country I ever saw for hundreds of miles.
Passed two isolated granite masses one on either hand and camped in a circle near the river and at the foot of a high hill. 10 ? miles
we passed the Saleratus Spring and stopped and gathered about 25 lb of Saleratus for our own use.
We are camped tonight on the river at the base of an imposing Butte about 250 feet high having traveled about 20 miles today.
After setting up camp Er Woodruff & I climbed a bluff. Kneeling tog. & offering prayers for the camp, the saints, & esp our dear families.
A company of Origon Emigrants are 5 miles in advance of us and another about the same distance in the rear.
starting at 7. Mr Young has a sore thumb. it paind dreadfully makes him sick.
Shortly after our start this morning, saw a grave near the road & a board w/ these words: Matilda Crowley, B. July 16 1830 & D. July 7 1846.
we're falling behind the camp on account of our horses walking faster than other teams and it fretted them.
we are behind 3/2 of a mile and one of our axletrees broke on the naked prarie without a stick of timber or any one near to help us.
Mr Young unharnessed one of his horses and started for camp. I was alone felt lonesome but Bro William Henry came back and staid with me.
we're looking round the waggon to find anything to hold up the wheel, we found a piece of timber that was calculated for a whip stock.
Passed the head board of a grave marked Matilda Crowly B. July 16th 1830 D July 7th 1846. In 1 ? mile crossed Cottonwood Creek.
we unloaded the hind part of the waggon, raised it up, lashed on the timber and was harnessing Bro Hs mare when Mr Young came back.
he harnessed his horse and we started for the camp. had not gone far when we met Bros Brigham, Woodruff, Benson and John Holman.
he's taking most of our load and on to the camp. the brethren went at it and put in an axeltree so we did not hinder the camp.
Halting for rest. Following the river bank, which is sandy and hard on teams.
Crossing the 2nd difficult creek of the day, Lorenzo Young broke an axle tree on his wagon. Some Missourians offering to take his load for a time.
We're splicing a stick of wood onto Lorenzo Young's axle tree. We hope this will enabled him to follow on to camp.
The bottom is level and dense with thrifty absinthe. Low range of granite on our right. Noon halt at the issuing of the river.
The main road should have led us across the river four times in 10 miles thus we have chosen to take a less frequent trail.
Deep sand and heavy wheeling on this trail. Weather is pleasant, however.
Cheered by a view of the "Wind River Chain" of the Rocky Mtns towering white w/ snow. Some peaks very high. Has a rough & broken appearance.
It has been verrey sandey & hevey whealing today. We now Can see the wind river mountains and they look verrey high.
One small Emigration Co. camped ?  mile above us and another1 ? mile, being the second that left the river Platte the morning we did.
2 Missouri companies camped near us, one abt 1/2 mile the other 1 mi away. We're  told that we have to travel 18 mi before next water.
We are again upon the river in a convenient camping ground with two companies of Emigrants in view before us, and one in our rear.
Missourian went ahead to examine the route &c. Hid in hills here from Indians but hasn't seen any. Says water is 14 mi and the pass is 28.
A small detachment from one of the Emigrant parties has dirven up to our camp to get our Blacksmiths to do some work for them.
In the distance at the right appears the towering heights of the Wind river chain of the Rocky Mts covered with immence bodies of Snow.
traveled 20/2 miles and camping for the night. we came in sight of the Rocky Mountains
Designed to make an early start, get ahead to get best feed at night. The other companies started half an hour ago, before we were ready.
We have arrived at two small lakes, one of which was very strongly impregnated with Salt & Sulphur & the other with Salt and Alkali.
At "Ice Spring." Under alkali water is a bed of clear ice. Some broke pieces off; it's sweet & refreshing. Ice at least 4" thick.
2 more alkali pools, white w/ saleratus. Many gathering it. If used at regular strength, bread turns green & smells like diluted copperas.
Our trail has left the river about a west course.
started at 6 drove 14 miles found a quagmire and an ice spring containing sulphur water and ice 1 ? inches thick.
the water that oosed out of the ice was good.
we also passed a spring of alkali and salt.
Grass indifferent. Spring water sulphery. Some pools brackish from the saline deposit. The valley has a slight smell like a salt marsh.
we traviled 17 3/4 miles today before we found a spot of grass suffi[c]ient to bait our teams on.
the roads was sandey and our teems tired and no outher camping place being <verrey near> we concluded to stop till anouther day
After traveling 17 3/4 miles, we have camped our teams being nearly exhausted from fatigue, hunger and thirst.
Formed encampment so as to enclose a bend in the river. The feed here is very good and plenty of willow bushes for fuel.
Reached Sweet Water again and camped. 17 ? miles. I walked it and got quite fatigued. A Sage hen was killed.

Holman had loaded rifle in his hand while walking Young's horse. Horse tried to go back. Holman unthinkingly urged the horse forward w/ his rifle--the cock caught & rifle fired a little forward of the nigh hind leg  of the horse.
Horse's belly has a large hole; it's bleeding freely. He cannot survive long & appears to be in great pain, the sweat falling from his forehead in large drops.
John Hollman accidently shot Prest. Young’s horse. It was considered the best horse in the camp.
While gathering the stock the Presidents saddle horse was shot through the body through the carelessness of a young man.
P Young filled w/ sorrow. Doesn't blame Holman, who grieves enough. Brethren sorrowful at 2nd accident w/ rifles killing a horse.
camping on the bank of the Sweet water. After we camped John Holman shot Bro Brighams John horse accidentally. was the best horse in camp.
The President's horse died during the night. He was the most highly priced of any horse in the camp.
President Young's horse is dead. Heading out soon to continue the journey.
On uneven, twisting, and very steep & unpleasant bluffs and sandy ridges. Crossing a narrow creek before we halt for dinner. Cold wind.
I bled at the lungs some last night and this morning. Did not sleep much. Crossed a small spring run of good water. 8 ? miles. Grass good.
It was quite warm in the morning but as we begn to rise and meet the cold blasts from the mountains of snow & Ice we gather our vests.
Some places are good hard road, in other places over rocks & loose fragments. Severe on wagons, requires great care in teamsters.
Came to a heavy bank of snow. Some of the brethren went to visit, and are amusing them selves by snow balling each other.
We pass drifts of snow and large bodies of Ice about the rivulets. We have put on our coats as it is very cold. The way has been rocky.
Dandelions and strawberries in full bloom also very large wild onions. A fine view of Wind River Mountains gleaming with snow and ice.
Fine view of the two Table rocks on the South side of the pass and Rocky Mountains. Myself and A. Carrington found a bank of snow.
The day was Colde and verrey windey. We ware traviling amidst the Rockey Mountains tho we had not reached the highest point.
? mile below camp is a grove of quaking asps covering five or six acres: some of them from eight to ten inches in diameter.
We found Snow and ice along the road. This is a cold Frozen part of the world and is far from being fit for humane beings to live in.
We have found a tolerable camping place on a mountain rivulet and are seeking our overcoats.
Some brethren brought ice 4-5" thick from north of camp. Creek banks have gooseberry bushes, strawberry roots & flowers, some white clover.
Have 1 gentile camp left to pass. Hope to do so soon so we have first pick of feeding areas and campgrounds. Nights exceedingly cold.
started early, had a hilly hard rough road. traveled 21 miles and camped for the night.
traveling thro most barren desolate country I ever saw. we anticipated seeing timber as we approached the Mountains but we were disappointed
Today is my birthday. I sat up with Prof. Orson Pratt and read California and Oregon papers by the light of a sage fire.
Our milk and water froze during the night as if it were winter.
Morning very cold. Considerable ice in water pails. Crossed 2 creeks this morning, 1 from springs to the south near a grove of small timber.
28°  at sunrise. Ice formed in the water pails. Crossed two good sized branches of the Sweet water, then crossed the Sweet water.
Crossed a branch of Sweetwater. Water clear & cold. A camping spot were it not so cold--large snow banks are both above and below the road.
This is a Cold morning. every thing Covered with frost and Ice in the water pails. It soon became warm again onley wind was colde
we came to Sweet water again and crost it and stop[p]ed to bait. The Snow lay in heapes under the north side of the bluffs
Went 6 miles out with Er Pratt. Found a small stream ascertained to be the head waters of the Pacific, the stream running towards the west.
After traveling 11 miles and crossing three more rivers, we have are at the place what is termed the foot of the Pass.
Every thing blooming. Grass good. As stock grazed, the children were snow balling on some deep snow bank at the foot of the hill.
came to the pass in the mountains. .
we have arrived at a small ridge which divides the waters flowing to the Gulf of Mexico from those that flow into the Gulf of California.
From Fort Larimie to this ridge according to our roadometer it is 246 1/2 miles.
Crossed another creek--this one superior to the last. We'll camp here.
Made camp. Seeing smoke ahead we found an old hunter named Moses Harris who came to pilot emigrants returning to the states.
if I could not look to the right and left I should not guess I was crossing the Rocky Mountains. it is the best road we have found for miles
we have traveled in sight of banks of snow for several days. when we stopped at noon we found snow 4 feet deep, good feed by the side of it
A Mr Harris from a company bound for Oregon has traveled this area much & is well informed in about the country & region of the salt lake.
After traveling about 19 miles, we have found a good camping place thanks to some of our men who followed up the Sweetwater.
Coming on a group of traders--8 men, abt 25 animals laden w/ packs of skins, robes &c. Several brethren hope to sent letters back by them.
We have sent letters back with some men from Oregon bound for the States.
At the dividing ridge of the "south pass." Er Pratt took a Barometrical observation and found the altitude to be 7085 feet.
Rolled on to keep ahead of the Emigration Co's. Crossed muddy springs, it being the first tributary of the Pacific we have crossed. 6 ? mi.
Satisfaction seeing the waters run westward instead of eastward. A mtn range in the distance, white w/ snow. Good grass here, no timber.
Mr. Harris brought 5 of the Oregon Paper, starting Feb 11th. Also a copy of the California Star published by Samuel Brannan in Yerba Buena.
We met a Comp. from Origon and olde mountainear who gave us not verrey favorable account of the countrey around Bear river or the salt lake.
Have little hope for moderate good country. Harris says the region is sandy, destitute of timber & vegetation, except for the Cache valley.
this day we have come to the waters of the green River. we are on the summit where the waters flow towards the Atlantic and Pacific.
Crossed a quicksand bed called "Dry Sandy.” Grass scanty. We are using sage, absinthe and grease bush for fuel. Mr. Harris came with us.
North and south breadth of grass from 20-25 miles. Gently rolling. One  hardly suspects they’re crossing the back bone of North America.
We traveled 15 1/4 miles today and camped upon another small tributary of the Sweetwater.
traveled 16 miles and camped on little Sandy. found poor feed
Aniversary of the cruel massacre of our beloved Joseph & Hyrum, 3 yrs. Lord has prospered our journey. We're beyond the reach of persecutors
Crossed the Little Sandy river.
Trading w/ Mr. Harris. He is well versed; it is hard to get a fair trade with him.
Have reached the grand fork in the roads. To the right leads to Oregon, to the left leads to California by the salt lake. That is our road.
Came to a fork in the road & We took the left for Ft. Bridger: the right going on more direct to Bear River bend.
Someone found a piece of petrified wood that looks like cottonwood. Appears to have rotted, broke off alive then petrified.
traveled 13 miles and stopped to bate near Big Sandy.
we met Capt Bridger of Bridger foort. he gave us more information in regard to the Salt lake countrey and the account was verrey favorable.
We camped early in consequence of meeting Mr. Bridger & two of his men bound for Fort Larrimie.
Crossing a small river--seemed easy at first, but the later wagons are having a harder time now that the bank is getting wet and soggy.
Noon halt on little Sandy. Distance 13 ? miles. Grass scanty. rossed little Sandy and met Mr. [Jim] Bridger and two men with him.
I was sick all day yesterday but feel a little better to day. this journey is very fatigueing. we feel almost wore out.
The men shall camped with us & give us much information relative to the roads, Streams and country generally.
Prest. Young and the twelve conversed with Mr. Bridger who spoke very favorably of our being able to find a good location on or near a lake.
Also south in Piute County where they raise wheat, corn &c. of the best quality. He bought of Moses Harris 3 deer skins and one elk skin.
Met w/ Mr Bridger, who told us much about what to expect about the salt lake and the region. Convinced that many of his stories are greatly exaggerated.
this afternoon traveled 7 miles and camped for the night
Mr. Bridger and men continued on to Ft. John. View very extensive over a level plain, bounded at a long distance by snow-capped mountains
Morning pleasant; growing hot. Today's road very, though barren. Halting for noon on the banks of the big sandy.
We have traveled 6 miles and must now cross the Big Sandy which is about the size of Sweet Water.
Rolled 6 ? miles to Big Sandy,  about 60 yds wide. The ford in Little Sandy and Big Sandy are said to be perfectly dry in the fall.
Pres Y & others ahead, looking for a campsite. Course about SW, road generally good: rolling, hard, parts covered w/ loose fragments of rock
After travelling 9? miles prest. Young rode up and reported that we have to go at least 11 miles further before we can get feed.
Warm day. The countrey was quite level and the Wind River Mountain was in plain vieue on the right
Have not found good feed for the stock or water. Will keep looking for a good camp.
Road hilly & uneven, in some places loose fragments of rock make bad travelling. Many rocks thrown off the road by the extra men.
Late making camp on Big Sandy. We crossed at 1:30 and made a slight ascent into a very extensive plain. 17 miles.
After 18 miles we've found a good camp.
Setting up camp by moonlight. Much grass, but no wood. Several men getting sick with severe fever, likely from exposure to dampness & water.
traveled 24 miles and camped on big sandy. did not get camped until after dark
Returning to camp w/ Pres Young after going ahead to view the road, etc. More men sick. Continuing our journey soon.
We struck the green River. It is scirted with bitter cotton wood of good Size, We had to make rafts to cross on
After 8 miles, we've reached the Green River & are setting up camp. The 2 divisions will make rafts.
Traveled 8 1/2 miles and have reached the Green River. We went to building rafts.
we've traveled 8 miles and come to green River.
Travelled 8 miles and nooned on the Green River. After dinner we were all busy washing, smithing, coal burning, and raft making.
I am feeling quite ill, with soreness in the flesh; and pain in the head and all parts of the body.
Samuel Brannon has arrived, coming from California to meet us. He is with a smith who caused problems after Joseph's death.
We reach Green River where we meet Samuel Brannan & others from California. The river is high.
We make some rafts. A great many brethren are taken with the Mountan fever
As the fever increases the pain in the head & back becomes almost insufferable. I fear it is Mountain Fever.
Bro. Brannan and 2 others came into our camp from California. He brought along the "California Star" which reports of our battalion in CA.
camped on the bank under the shade of some trees which was a treat. I assure you they being the only one we'd seen for some hundred miles.
I have begun my baking and washing and so on. the men went to building a raft
This day Bro Brannon came to us from Callifornia he brought a good report from the countrey and the brethren in that countrey.
Meeting with the 12 and Brannon to hear his report. 11 died on the ship journey. The saints are growing grain in abundance.
Geo. Wardle is quite unwell—severe cold and high fever. Many others are also, owing probably to fatigue and exposure to the cool night air.
From South Pass to this crossing are strong indications of iron, coal, lead and copper. Both of our rafts were finished about dark.
comenced crossing the River. the Brethren were atacked with the mountain fever and likewise Clarra. she was very sick during the night
2nd division has finished their raft; we'll begin ferrying the wagons over now.
Drove some cattle in twice to swim across the river but they would not. Our raft sat over 5 wagons until the wind forced us to quit.
Wind is picking up, impeding our progress. 2nd division's raft is too soggy to work; another needs to be made.
we Commenced crossing the river, This river is about 40 rods wide and the currint is heavey it was a harde job to cross over
In the process of crossing the Green river. More men are afflicted with Mountain Fever. I feel quite weak and feeble as do others.
Second division raft abandoned and another built from twenty five to ten feet. First division crossed over 4 more wagons, making 10 in all.
After a hard day's toil, we succeed in getting only 14 wagons over the river. More men are falling ill to the fever.
Gentiles behind us report similar fevers--and deaths. We have no deaths and don't expect any. The first to be ill are recovering.
Both rafts busy. Just before sunrise we swam over quite a number of cattle and horses.
our waggons are crossing the River this morning.
2nd division has finished their second raft and will commence ferrying, including my wagon and Pres Young's.
We are still ferrying our loads across the river on the rafts we have built. We hope to finish tomorrow.
we finished and went on 3 miles down the river about south.
Some of the sick getting better and others taking sick with what is called in this country, camp fever. Geo. Wardle is a little better.
The 12 in council plan to send 3 or 4 brethren to meet the next company & serve as pilots. Letter of instructions ordered to be wrote.
Clara is better. John Young Greene is taken down with the fever. Samuel Brannen met us at Green River from California
I was considerably unwell. Nearly all the stock all all the wagons but eighteen over safe and sound.
After another day of ferrying, only 20 wagons remain for tomorrow.
Morning is stormy. Brethren resuming ferrying the last wagons while others go ahead to find a new campsite.
remaining in camp today
The last of the wagons is safely over. The cattle and other animals crossing now. We feel grateful for the safe crossing.
Storm is picking up. Brethren returned and reported a good camping site about 4 miles from here.
I am much better as is Bro. Geo. Wardle. Cloudy & cool, thundered and showered a little. We are all over safe.
All safely over, we are heading for a camp to make for Sunday.
Approaching camp, cattle, horses & men are covered with musquitoes. I don't recollect of ever seeing more in any place in my life.
Started to travel between three and four keeping near the river, the clay, sand and gravely road making it heavy traveling. Camped.
Musquetoes very thick. Nearly opposite on the cliffs is an overhanging of indurated green clay or marl from 100-150 feet high.
Pres Young addressed the men about trading at Ft Bridger, to not throw away their goods but to be wise & prudent.
Orders given to congregate for prayer meeting and to hear from the bishops.
We lay still. Sent 4 or 5 men back to meet and pilot the companies over.
Thirteen men of the Mormon Battalion came up under Sergeant T.S. Williams.
They are gladly received by three cheers & thanks to God that so many have returned from the army.
Sent a letter to my father. P. Young, E. Glines, R. Badger, A. Farr and G. Woodward went back to meet our next company.
They’ll tell them about camp places and help their own families. One of Bro. John Brown's oxen died.
We've decided to leave a raft tied on each side of the river so they're ready for those going either direction.
We stayed at this place and sent five men back to meet the camp that was Comming after us to take dispatches and guide them on.
sent back four men to meet the other company.
Five brethren chosen to go back to help the companies that follow--seems prudent to send those with families coming along behind us.
5 men were back with letters to our brethren of the next company & to Pilot them over.
13 brethren came up with us from the army. we received them with 3 cheers and Hosannas to God and the lamb that so many returned in saftyns
12 of our battalion from Pueblo arrived, well armed and mounted. They left their company at North Fork, crossing. A Lyman is with them.
a good meney of the Camp has been taken sick. They was taken sick with a pain in the head and back. attended with a feaver.
Today a part of a detachmant from the mormon Batalion came up with us. They were on their way to Fort Bridger.
1 of Bro Crows oxen found poisoned by eating a weed or plants which grows here. It was badly swelled and I understand was dead when found.
Clear and pleasant. The sick are getting better.
We have been unable to find water all day.
After 21 miles without water we have struck Ham's Fork and made camp although it is the middle of the afternoon.
Camped on Blacks Fork at 5 pm. 20 miles. Grass en route to none and very poor around camp. Caught a fine fish resembling salmon trout.
The edges of the table mounds and the bluffs of Blacks Fork are composed of indurated green clay, gray marl and earthy limestone.
we kept down green river a fue miles then left it and struck over on Ham's fork, campt. traviled 20 mile
traveled 20 miles through a sandy desolate country and see nothing but sage
Have arrived at a stream 4 rods wide.
Kept up Black's fork and then Ham's for about 4 miles. Crossed Hams fork at a good ford about 20 yards wide. Grass good and fuel plenty.
We have come upon another tributary of Green river, the Black river. The current is strong and our wagon beds scarcely clear the water.
Camped on Black fork bank. 18 ? miles. Grass good. Cottonwoods, red willows, currant bushes, thrifty berries, rose bushes. . .
. . . dandelions seeding, flax seeding and thrifty, thistle in bloom, small trees very like crab apples.
12 miles without water and we have come to the Black river once again.
The names of the fords are according to Fremonts map. Geo. A. Smith is quite unwell with the Mountain fever.
We crossed the Black river for a second time and will now make camp, having traveled 18 miles today.
Struck on Blacks fork. Went 18 1/2
traveled all day through the hardest kind of a road.
I shall skip to entering the valley on account of my health, the fatigue of traveling, and with my labor prevent my keeping a daily journal
Fording Blacks Ford once more. There is abundance of good grass, wild flax and handsome flowers.
Halting at another creek for rest. Some of the wagons have gone on, expecting to reach Bridgers Fort before they halt.
Some distance on our left a long range of snowy mountains, extending north west and south east.
We reach Fort Bridger and meet some men returning from Oregon by whom I sent a letter home
From here we take the route to Salt Lake at Bear River. Here we meet a company from California.
The river separats into 7 or 8 riffles and creeks which flow over an extensive bottom which divide it into numerous Islands we must cross.
Mr. Miles Goodyear is in the company. He gives us much information in relation to the country. He had a fort of the lake near Weber river.
2  miles below Farr's Bridger, the Oregon trail turns off. Crossed 7 mountain streams, passed 17 Snake Indian lodges. Bridger's Fork.
Arrived near 9 Indian Lodges. Tim Goodall here, 1 of the trappers who passed at the Platte ferry. The few Indians here have handsome ponies.
Bridgers Fort, so called, consists of two long, low, rough cabins built in the form of an L with a small enclosure for stock.
We will make camp a little above its trading house haveing traveld 18 miles today. Here we will rest ourselves & teams one day.
Having forded four more creeks. Passing Fort Bridger now. Will likely go a little farther--and cross more creeks--before setting up camp.
Crost Blacks fork a number of times and camped near Ft bridger It consists of three log rooms and a small yard inclosed with pickets.
The boys have caught several fine black spotted trout. I am still quite unwell.
I was taken verrey violentley sick on Monday with the Complaint that was in the Cam
Grass plentiful in this neighborhood. Whole region seems covered w/ rapid streams, doubtless from the melting of the snow on the mtns.
I do not know as I ever expearanced more pain the same lingth of time in my life than I did through monday night. mostley in my hips & back.
I am nowe on the mend but am hardley able to walk. There is new cases about every day and what will be the end the Lord onley knowes.
Quite a frost. Snow range Eute Mountains, part of Bear River Chain about fifteen miles south of us. Wind south west.
We'll remain here today to mend wagons and tires. Many going to the Fort to trade. I'm sending brother Egan to trade for me.
There is timber and plenty of good feed and indeed this is about the first pleasant looking Spot I have seen west of the Pass.
W/ the 2 rifles I sent, Bro Egan got 20 pretty good buck skins. I consider that to be a pretty good trade. Some going fishing in the creek.
We are trading with the traders at the fort & with the French & Indians. Their skins & Peltry are as high as they were in the States
Lying by to fix wagons, shoe horses, trade &c. I feel better. Latitude of Fort Bridger by observation of Prof. Orson Pratt 41°19'13".
We stopped all day frost this morning some new cases of sickness
In council listening to complaints from Mills against Gibbons. Both appear at fault & are being advised to be more careful & not get angry.
Discussing Er Brannan & Williams. They're to return to meet Captn Brown from Pueblo to be discharged & get their pay from the U.S.
On the road--it's very rough today. Brothers Brannan and Williams at the same time starting back to meet the company.
We've chosen a blind trail the general course of which is a little South of west, leading in the direction of the Salt Lake.
Clear and warm. Started at about 8 a.m. and took Hastings new road. After 6 ?  miles stoped to water our stock at a fine spring run.
Fortunately for us a party of Emigrants passed this way last fall though their trail is now in many places scarcely discernable.
Ascended a long, steep hil. The top of this ridge tolerably level for several miles, but we'll have to descend to the lower land again.
Going down the hill. The descent is the steepest & most difficult we have ever met with, being lengthy & almost perpendicular.
Crossing the Muddy Fork. We'll camp on the other side. I'ts a good chance for teams to fill themselves in the abundance of tall bunch grass.
we traviled 19 miles and camped on muddey. The road has been hilley & stooney. My health is on the mend but I am quite feeble.
Roads good, soil clay. Grass at camp good and plentiful. Several, in camp, sick. Latitude 41°16'11", observation by Prof. Orson Pratt.
We are making camp 13 1/2 miles from Bridger after miles of ascent and passing many drifts of snow on this winding trail.
Ascended a long stony hill, passed over an elevated sage plain and descended a long steep hill to muddy Creek. Distance ? mile. Made camp.
Thin ice in the bucket. A fine spring of excellent water between our camp and the first rise.
At a copperas spring, clear,tastes of copperas & alum. Leaves a singular feeling in the mouth. Water almost looks like blood at a distance.
After passing through several fertile vallies we are now crossing two of the most rugged hills we have passed on our Journey.
More steep ascents and descents today, with huge rocks that leave just enough space for a wagon to get through.
Professor Albert Carrington has discovoured some Blossom of Stone coal which has been supposed not to exist in this region of country.
Have reached dividing ridge between Colorado waters & Great Basin. Mtn's ascent is very steep. Must make a crooked road to gain the summit.
Road forks to Bear River or off south. A fine spring of mineral tar exudes from hill 1 ? mi. away near south road. Excellent, edible roots.
3 bears are running up the side of the mountain. The hunters are trying to chase them, but it doesn't appear they'll have luck.
Some bad hills and verrey stoney. Some small fine vallies. went 14 mile
Descending again on the west side. It's so steep we'll have to lock the wagons for at least a mile. Most mountainous country I've ever seen.
We traveled 18 miles today and made camp. We Perceive a smoke on the river. Myself & several others are riding down to investigate.
Camp assembled. Voted to take the northern route. There is a fine sulphur spring 200 yds south of where the road comes to the rivulet.
Met Mr. Goodier from Bear river valley. Wants us to go through his way, not by SL. Many believe he wants us to make a road to his place.
The smoke was from a camp of men direct from the settlements in California. From them we obtained late papers & news of the Mexican war.
we lay by
We shall remain in our place for today.
Road forks to Bear River or off south. A fine spring of mineral tar exudes from hill 1 ? mi. away near south road. Excellent, edible roots.
Thin ice in the bucket. A fine spring of excellent water between our camp and the first rise.
Brother Jesse Little & myself explore the route the camp did not move.
Pres. Young & I went to the top of a mtn east of the camp to see the surrounding valley. Much timber and snow. We prayed, Young being mouth.
Descending the mtn, we found a spring, the surface covered w/ flower of sulpher. A black substance oozes out. Water smells bad, of sulpher.
We've found a Spring of mineral Tar or Bituminous Pitch. Some of our men filled up their Tar bucket & used it for wheel grease.
lay by all day.
An oil spring discovered--bears a resemblance to tar. Some oil gun stocks, others shoes. Some gone filling buckets to grease wagon wheels.
Camp assembled. Voted to take the northern route. There is a fine sulphur spring 200 yds south of where the road comes to the rivulet.
Hearing report of bro. Little concerning the road. We'll vote which road to take. General feeling of the 12 is to follow the south road.
Fording Bear River, a rapid stream. The bottom is full of large cobble stones. Banks lined w/ willows & strawberry vines. Soil looks rich.
We shall cross the bear river. It is about 2 feet deep, with a rappid currant running north.
The president is taken sick.
Forded Bear River, 30 rods wide, 2 feet deep. Current rapid, the bed stony. Soil redish, yellowish & white clay. Vegetation more abundant.
The mountain Sage has in a great measure given place to grasses a variety of Prairie flowers and shrub ceders upon the sides of the hills
not quite so bad hills, crossed Bare Creek. the soile looks better more and herbiage were plenty on the hills.
Near needle cliffs. he stops with 8 waggons. the camp goes on to the caves.
9 ? miles. 3 lopes killed. A long ascent ahead to quite an elevation. Prest. Young and a few wagons stayed at noon halt. He was sick.
Passed a small spring of good, clear cold water. Halting for noon at a narrow pass, near a ridge of high, broken rocks. 9 1/2 miles today.
Elder Heber C. Kimball rode in, reported the President better but Col. Rockwood worse. Slight shower from the south west and thunder.
President Young was taken sick today and stoped with a fue outher waggeons. my health remains verrey poor so that I am hardey able to walk.
It was thought best to send on a fue teems and men to look out and fix the road and the remanider with most of the sick to stop a day or two.
Time to move on, but Young is too sick to be moved. We'll tarry until he gets some better. 8 wagons stopped here, 3 of which are mine.
Prest. Young couseled 33 wagons under Prof. Pratt to start on to fix road to Weber River Kanyon & survey Reeds cut off, while sick rest.
Fine view of the mountain, dale and valley. Snowfree, green and beautiful, abundant vegetation. Descended to a fine spring. Grass good.
The rest are gone on. Young was insensible part of the afternoon. Br Rockwood is also very sick & mostly insensible with fever.
Vale abounding in good grasses. Good spring. Lopes killed. Road good. Soil a dark loam. A fine cave. Little rain--a brilliant rainbow.
We have found excellent spring water & the best feed for our stock we have had on our route. We have named this camp Mathew's Vale.
As Pres. Young and many others have taken seriously ill, we shall rest here for another day. And advance party will be sent ahead.
We find him at the same place. Verry sick.
Some clouds but very pleasant. The President did not come up last night. Some men went back to see him. I am much better.
Young and Rockwood remain very sick. John Brown & Joseph Mathews returned & reported that they are 6? miles ahead of us.
The president still has not come up.
23 of the best teams were selected with the ablest men and sent to prepare the way over the Lake Mount around the Weber River Canion.
The camp stops here and Brother Matthews and myself go back to see what detains him.
Returned w/ Brown & Mathews. Called a mtg & proposed the company go ahead w/ Er Pratt, hunt out the route, improve & make a good road.
Brother Kimball returns with us to camp and draws out a company of  23 waggons to go ahead and prepare road.
which now began to be very rough. This detachment is commanded by Elder O. Pratt. my company is selected to go among+others
Egan and I returned back to our camp, accompanied by George A. Smith. Found Prest. Young a little better.
I went to see the Prest. and returned about dark and reported to the camp that Prest. B. Young and Colonel A. P. Rockwood quite sick.
Some cloudy but quite warm. Pleasant breeze from the South West. Several in camp sick with the fever.
Decided to form a new camp in the morning.
Ers Woodruff and Barney Adams came from the other camp to see the sick who are much better.
Those of us left in camp continue to rest and prepare for the remaining journey. Many are still sick.
Er Woodruff has decided to bring his carriage in the morning to carry prest. Young, as he thinks he will be able to ride some then.
We reach the Weber. Here there are two trails. One goes down to the river through the canyon.
The other turns out to the south.
Brother Pratt and myself who act as pioneers and pilots for the camp go down and examine the canyon but do not find it practicable.
We examine the other route to the south through which a small company of emigrants from California had passed the year before.
But we can scarcely see their trail.
Went to the top of a mtn w/ Ers Benson & Lorenzo. Offered up  prayers in behalf of the sick, for our families and the saints &c.
We found scattering flax of a good size and quality. The valley was furtile but verrey narrow
the hills on boath sides ware several hundred feet high and on the right hand it was rock. In maney places it was difficult passing.
Elders Woodruff and Adams taking supper with me and will then returned back to their camp.
A slight shower after dark.
Er Woodruff has arrived with his carriage for Young to ride in. Our company is now proceeding on towards the other camp
we followed down the valey til we came to the Canion, but choosing if possable to find a better pas and to avoide passing down...
...some ten miles in the in the head of the river we stoped for the day and sent men in differant wayes to find a better way if possable.
Have arrived at the other camp. Giving orders to get their team up so we can go a few miles further. A very refreshing shower raining on us.
A light thunder show, then Prest Young came up. The sick are nearly all better. More light thunder showers.
With many of the sick on the mend, we are heading down the Vale. The President & Col. Rockwood riding upon a bed in a carriage.
Proceeded onward about 45 min ago. Just passed a spring of very good water, at the foot of a high hill a little to the right of the road.
Started at 2, proceeded 2 miles and passed 2 good springs. Grass good and plentiful. Camped, making 4 ? miles. 3 good springs.
Forming our encampment at the foot of some high red bluffs. Feed here is plentifull. A spring of good cold water is near the road.
Plenty good grass, willows, sage and dwarf white cedar. I went to the top of the hill north of camp. View west cut off by high ridges.
Had 2 pleasant showers w/ loud thunder this morning. Proceeding again, the sick being still some better.
Crossed a deep ravine where many teams need help to get over. Now crossing a creek--very bad crossing place. 1 wagons broke down.
We send a messenger back to the main camp to report progress and bring us word from the brethren.
Made a new place to cross which detained us an hour. Mtns are higher & nearer together, leaving but a narrow pass for the creek & a road.
6 ? mi. 2 fine springs, quaking asps, good grass. Vertical cliffs of yellow, gray and reddish sandstone capped with pudding stone.
O.P. Rockwell came back from Er Pratts company. They found the mtn road avoiding the Kanion & expect to reach the summit by noon.
O. P. Rockwell returned from the advance company and reported. >20 miles to the fork of Reeds cut off Kanyon road. We started off.
Our descent has been very rappid all day but we have passed through some extensive Patches of what Mountainers call wild wheat.
Space between mtns very narrow, many bad creek crossings. Passed Oak shrubbery, wild gooseberries, Hop vines, Elder bushes & black brick.
We found our way up a revean to the top of the hill verrey difficult to assent for about 7 miles and a rise of about from 4 to 500 feet.
The whole camp seemed perfectly Immerged in a Dense thicket of large Shrubbery and weeds, with scattering trees which fill the valley.
The road down the same vale good. 6 spring runs crossed at steep banks. 7 Mi. Camped. Grass tolerable. Water from a run.
Prest. Young is quite fatigued with the days journey and does not feel so well.
Lyman Curtis was taken sick this evening and I was not hardley able to sit up which made thing look rather gloomey--
We traveled 16? miles & are making camp about a mile from the Main Fork of Weber River.
Prest. Young has had a very sick night. One of the black smith's forge's was set up and some wagons repaired.
Move over onto Big Canyon Creek.
Brother Pratt and myself go ahead to explore the route which led up the creek in a southern direction.
After setting out, the President became unable to ride. He is still quite ill. We are making camp 2 1/2 miles from last night's encampment.
Have arrived at the red fork of Weber River. Banks lined with cottonwood, birch & underwood. Pres. Young not able to travel today.
We could scarcely get along for the brush. We go up where the road leaves the creek and ascend a big mountain on the left of the road.
Prest. Young quite sick last night and this morn. Began at 10, reached mouth of Red Fork, camped. Prest. Young not able to travel. 2 ? mi.
We see nothing but mountains except a beautiful park which lay up the creek.
We are offering up united Prayers, in behalf of Pres. Young & the sick in our camp, the Saints who are following & our wifes & children.
The Pioneers, twelve (except Prest. Young, who was sick) Amasa Lyman with Browns detachment and W. Woodruff were hunting horses.
The ice was as thick window glass this morning. Br O Pratt and John Brown went on to examin the rout and outhers went to work fixing bad places.
We have found numerous small towers of a stone resembling old factory or furnace chimneys.
we started on and crosed over a hill and Came on to a creek and followead it up. we had to cros it a number of times which was hard to cross
Ers Richards, G.A. Smith, Benson & others going to a high mtn. We'll clothe ourselves & offer prayers for Young & for the sick generally.
10 brethren repaired to the mountains, clothed, prayer by W. Richards, signs and prayer by H. C. Kimball, signs &tc and prayer by self.
Riding out w/ Smith, Howard, & Egan to see the Kanion, but was further than expected. W/ night coming in, we returned back w/out seeing it.
frost & ice this morning
Advised the camp to meet for prayer instead of hunting, fishing, climbing mountains &c. They're building a bower for that purpose.
Being Sunday we lay by.
We are having a prayer meeting in camp remembering before the Lord the case of the Prest. & the sick in camp.
Prest. better. At 10 a.m. prayer meeting. Voted that all go on in the morning except a few wagons that the President may be more retired.
Proposing that the camp, except a few wagons & men to attend Young, go on tomorrow & when they find a good place, start plowing & planting.
My proposition met the minds of the brethren and decided accordingly.
We have begun a meeting for breaking bread and instruction and exhortation.
Brethren meeting again. Bishops will administer the sacrement, after I and several others of the Twelve will speak to the brethren.
We had an excellent meeting. The Holy Spirit was upon us and faith seemed to Spring up in every Bosom.
Quite warm. Met at 2. Sacrament administered. Elder H. C. Kimball gave some good teachings.
Said Kimball, Prest. had been washed and anointed all over and then slept. Awoke looking like a new man and would be able to go on soon.
The President who had been nigh unto Death is sensibly Better. The effects of the Prayer of the Brethren are visable throughout the camp.
the weather is verrey hot through the day, we stoped to rest today and Br Pratt delivered a good discourse by way of incourigemant &c.
The day has been very hot and prest. Young yet remains very sick.
We go ahead as usual to explore the route. Go as far as the Big Mountain where we view the valley for the first time.
Young some better. The 41 wagons going ahead out abt 20 min ago. 15 wagons are behind. 3 of mine wagons are gone, 3 remain here.
The President and the twelve thought it not advisable for the camp to wait longer for him and about forty teams will leave our encampment.
President Young better. Started at about 8 a.m. Soon after the President and the few in company came on a short distance.
We have instruction to follow the advance company and halt at the first suitable Spot and put in our seed Potatoes, Buckwheat and Turnips.
We go on to the mountain to the right and run into a corner of what we suppose to be Salt Lake.
Followed Weber River 3 ? miles and crossed. Soon struck a spring rim. Crossed it two or three times and rose to the top of Platte Pass.
The balance of the camp concluded to moved lower doun the river. We'll go about 1 1/2 miles and then set up camp again.
We send back intelligence and all rejoice. Our messenger returns and brings message that the president is better.
Our descent through this canyon is over a rough road, which we makes it necessary to stop and repair often. We ascend again.
White heads above the intervening mountains show us Plainly that our climbing was not yet at an end.
Flies are very troublesome to our horses. Have arrived back at camp Found Young some better. The sick are generally recovering.
Camped on the Weber. Distance 13 ? miles. From this ridge you can see snow mountains, about 20 miles ahead, stretching across our route.
We have stoped tonight upon a small patch of grass surrounded by the thick shrubbery upon this creek haveing traveled 13 3/4 miles.
we followed up the creek south and crosed it 8 or 9 times. It is truley a difficult passage. the land on the streems is rich
we Came about 7 miles this day. goos bierys are plentey in maney places on these creeks.
I am fatigued & wore out with riding and constant exercise riding ahead to select camping places &c, but my health continues good.
Young improving. We concluded to go & travel in the cool of the morning. After 1 mi, we're fording a river--good crossing w/ a hard bottom
About 3/4 mi past the ford, we put up a sign: "Pratts Pass to avoid the Kanion. From Fort Bridger 74? miles."
Frost, ice in the bucket. Nights cool, days hot. A small coal pit burnt last night.
Some of the sick feel unable to ride over so rough a road. Three wagons will wait until the Pres. and rear company overtake them.
We left canion creek this morning and struck up a revien. our Journey for a number a day had been desolate.
the mountains on baoth sides was verey high and the revien so crooked that we could not see but a short distance...
...and it looked as tho we were shut up in a gulf without aney chance for ascape
Camp halted to rest and is now back on the road. I'm riding ahead w/ Benson to find a campground, as Young cannot go much further.
Travel is through dense thickets and we cross the creek often. We also stop to repair roads and cut away Brush.
There are 3 wagons at today's camp site who started with the other company--Goddard, Case & Wm. Smoot. They stopped on account of sickness.
Distance 7 ? miles. So narrow in groves that one cannot walk and drive. Bro. Wardle is much better. 3 wagons and 6 men (3 sick) tarried.
We camp tonight where Elder Pratt's company camped last night. We have found a letter left by Elder Pratt for us.
Elders Richards & Smith determined on Sending me in the morning with a letter to overtake Elder Pratt & accompany him to the valley.
Geo. Wardle quite unwell last night Crossed kanyon fork 11 times.  Road work. Road stony and the hardest we have had on wagons.
We pass by a creek that is called Browns Creek and the gap in the mountains is called Pratt's Pass.
Young feels quite feeble this morning by the fatigue of yesterday's journey. Consequently it's considered best to remain here til tomorrow.
I am on horseback heading westward the Summit of the Mountains. The revine is very narrow and mountains rise on either side.
I have my first sight of the valley of the Utah some 15 miles from the Summit.
W/ E Benson & L Young, visiting the Kanion below. The creek runs between high mtns for near half a mile.
Ascended to kanyon top. Fine view of ragged mountains ranges and also a fine valley. Soil rich and quick. Vegetation rank
Good spring run which we crossed often. Cleared timber and thickets. Ascended to the top of the divide between this and another run.
We tried walking down into the Kanion, but couldn't go further than 1/2 way.
We soon left that revein and crosed a verrey hevey hill about 1/2 mile up. we then desended down into anouther revian, we went about 7 miles
I have overtaken Elder Pratt where the trail enters a rocky canyon. It will take much labor to make a passable road through the thickets.
We returned back to camp and found prest. Young much better. Er Sherwood and the other sick brethren are also better.
We are ascending a very steep rise to reach a butte we hope will command a view of the valley.
At the same instant, Elder Pratt and I uttered a shout of Joy at finding the  broad Bason of the Salt Lake Spreading itself Before us!
We are descending into the valley to get a better look. Crossing many streams.
Cannon wagon on Bro. Frost's team gave out. Descent long and very steep. Road rough. Camped after dark teams on wagons about 13 hours.
Within ? mi of advance co. Wheat grass. Cottonwood, fir, few sugar oaks, box elders, &c. Berries plentiful. Limestone. Teams tired, dusty.
Returned to camp to find them 3 miles past where we left them at noon. Pres. Young's party is 1/2 mile behind them.
Have traveled 2 miles. Case rode in, reports 1 of his wheels has broke down. I'll go assist with Benson & Egan. Camp will wait nearby.
We started again with seven others to explore the valley further and mark a road down the creek.
We cut a pole for Cases's wheel & lashed it under the wagon, putting Benson's horse ahead of Case's & hauled the wagon to camp.
Emerged to view the southeast part of the Great Salt Lake with 3 ragged ranges of mountains in sight. The valley is 8-10 miles across.
Myself, Orson Pratt and others explored the kanyon. Found saline portion of valley abounding in hot mineral springs. Killed rattlesnakes.
We are examining a small canyon we feel will make a practical road down the Bed of the creek through the Canyon.
a host of the Camp that we had left came up with us and outhers had to stop because of sickness. our moove was sloe
We left a note upon a pole recommending the better road before taking down to the valley. We're crossing marshes and salt plains.
Back at camp. Divided Cases's load into other wagons and proceeded on again.
8 or 10 of us explore the valley we find it covered with rich vegetation in the vicinity of the streams and the lowlands green & beautiful
it took all the able spair hands from 1/2 to 3/4 of the time to fix the road so that we could possabley git along.
Crossed a bad slough. 1 of Lorenzo's horses mired. Found letter left in a stick by O Pratt. Says where they are, what to expect on the road.
1/4 mi on, making encampment. Today travelled 7? miles over rough, crooked road, thick bushes of willows. Crossed creeks 12 times.
We've found a warm spring that although we can't know the tempature seems about right for scaldiing hogs.
Several hot springs and sulpher. A great many black crickets all over the valley but appear harmless. the camp comes into the valley.
Here are the greatest facilities for a Steam Doctor I ever saw. A stone in the center of the stream seemed ready for the Patient.
At any rate I tried it, but had little desire to remain long upon it. All these main Springs are very strongly impregnated with Salt & Sulphur.
We had to pas through a Canion that was full of timber mostley maple of a small groath and the mountains came almost togeather at the bottom
But when we got through it seamed like bursting from the confine of a prison.
We came ful vieu of the S.E. part of the grait Salt Lake that we had ben so long looking for. It was about 30 miles off.
Pretty stream. Plenty mosquitoes after dark. Soil quick and fertile. A few trees nearly one foot through near the mouth of the kanyon.
Moved north at 7 to edge of the valley and camp met. Prayer by Prof. Orson Pratt. Remarks were made by Bros. Pratt and Richards & others.
Ascending a high mtn. Road passes a ravine and gradually though rapidly ascends. It's rough & rocky, making bad travelling.
We went a short distance to a small groav and cambed. Br P.P. Pratt called the Camp togeather
masures was entered into for puitting in oure potatoes earley corn, buck wheat, turnips, &tc. Plowes was started and some planting don
We have commenced with our preperations for planting seeds.
A committee appointed to pick out ground for planting. 40 X 20 rods staked off for potatoes at 11:15. First furrow turned by noon.
Have arrived at the summit. Have a fine view of the snow mountains and the valley of the Salt Lake in the distance south west.
Descending the steep hill, it's necessary to lock the hind wagon wheels. Road winds over a rough road caused by stumps of trees left.
Dam on run for irrigation began. 3 ploughs running and1harrow. 2 ? acres ploughed. Grass mowing for turnip patch. Prarrie hens. Milkweed.
Lorenzo's wagon turned over. His 2 little boys were inside. They were taken out by cutting a hole through the wagon cover & weren't hurt.
Pack & Mathews rode in. Reported both companies abt 14 miles ahead encamped about 25 miles from the Salt Lake, which is visible to them.
Brethren ahead prepare to move on & start planting. A letter from O. Pratt, G.A. Smith & W. Richards accounts the roads, features, &c.
We found the soile to be good and that we were out of the reach of our enemies and that God had blessed us on oure Journey verry mutch.
Camping on the banks of "last creek," a small stream of cool water. The sky is growing overcast & has the appearance of a very heavy storm.
The sick gaining strength as fast as can be expected. This day has been the hottest since Winter Quarters, & the hardest on our horses.
Major Pack reported the President and co. were few miles back and much better. Teams to come in 4 hour tours: 4 tours, 4 a.m. to 8 p.m.
Some cloudy but quite warm.
Started early. Find the road very rough & uneven to the mouth of the Kanion, 4? miles from where we started. Ascending a steep pitch.
At the top of the pitch. I behold the Great valley of the Salt Lake spreading before us.
Moving on. Came in sight of the other camp soon. The balance of the road is good and rapidly descending for several miles.
Our camp on the south side of city creek. Preparations are made. Fields Ploughed and the president arrives in the valley.
Br. Young and the remainder of the Camp cam up which gave us mutch joy and we had a time of rejoysing together.
Have arrived amongst the brethren. Today traveled 12? miles. The total distance from Fort Bridger 116 miles & from Fort John 573 miles.
The President & all the rear of the Pioneer company arrived, their health much improved.
Potatoes all planted. I planted first. At about two the President and his company came up, all better.
this day we arrived in the valley of the great Salt Lake.
my feelings were such as I cannot describe. every thing looked gloomy and I felt heart sick
Water let on the ground. Towards evening a slight shower.
We have the creek dammed up and water turned onto our land and several acres of Potatoes & early corn Planted.
Had an excellent meeting. All feel satisfied that the Lord had led us to this very Spot for a Stake of Zion.
